title: who says coronavirus emergency is public enemy number one
story: Quarantine officials on the Diamond Princess cruise ship that has been quarantined in Japan. Photograph: David AbelFacebookPA WireChina’s coronavirus outbreak poses a “very grave threat for the rest of the world” and should be viewed as “public enemy number one”, the head of the World Health Organisation said on Tuesday.WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus urged countries to step up measures to detect and contain the virus, especially in at least 30 countries with weaker health systems, where it could “create havoc”.The virus has been named Covid-19, for coronavirus disease 2019, with no geographical association, he said.Mr Tedros, referring to some governments’ counter-terrorism measures, said: “To be honest, a virus is more powerful in creating political, economic and social upheaval than any terrorist attack.“A virus can have more powerful consequences than any terrorist action. If the world doesn’t want to wake up and consider this enemy virus as public enemy number one, I don’t think we will learn from our lessons,” he said.China has reported 42,708 confirmed confirmed cases, including 1,017 deaths, Mr Tedros said, noting that there were fewer than 400 cases in 24 other countries with one death.The WHO began a two-day meeting in Geneva, where it appealed for sharing virus samples and speeding up research into drugs and vaccines.“The first vaccine could be ready in 18 months. So we have to do everything today using the available weapons to fight this virus while preparing for the long term using the preparations for the vaccines,” Mr Tedros said.“With 99 per cent of cases in China, this remains very much an emergency for that country, but one that holds a very grave threat for the rest of the world,” he told more than 400 researchers and national authorities, including some taking part by video conference from mainland China and Taiwan. Hong KongMr Tedros, speaking to reporters on Monday, had referred to “some concerning instances of onward transmission from people with no travel history to China”, citing cases this week in France and Britain. Five British nationals were diagnosed with the coronavirus in France, after staying in the same ski chalet with a person who had been in Singapore. “The detection of this small number of cases could be the spark that becomes a bigger fire. But for now it’s only a spark. Our objective remains containment,” he said.Hong Kong residents evacuated from a residential building where a man and woman confirmed with coronavirus live tested negative for the virus, health authorities said on Tuesday, easing concerns of a cluster of the outbreak in the Chinese-ruled city.Many questions remain about the origin of the virus, which emerged at a wildlife market in the central Chinese city of Wuhan in December, and is spread by people in droplets from coughing or sneezing.“We hope that one of the outcomes of this meeting will be an agreed roadmap for research around which researchers and donors will align,” Mr Tedros told the meeting. China’s foremost medical adviser on the outbreak, Zhong Nanshan, said numbers of new cases were falling in some provinces and forecast the epidemic would peak this month. “I hope this outbreak or this event may be over in something like April,” said Mr Zhong (83), an epidemiologist who won fame for his role in combating an outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome in 2003.Off Japan’s port of Yokohama, the Diamond Princess cruise ship with 3,700 passengers and crew remained quarantined, with the number of confirmed cases at 135. Thailand said it had barred passengers from getting off another ship, Holland America Line’s MS Westerdam, even though no confirmed infections have been found on board.– Reuters

title: von der leyen surprised at uk suggestion of australia style eu relationship
story: European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen and Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier in Strasbourg on Tuesday. Photograph: Jean-Francois BadiasAPBoris Johnson’s suggestion that the UK could be prepared to accept an Australian-style relationship with the EU without a formal trade deal has “surprised” Brussels. European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen pointed out that even Australia wants a better trading relationship with the bloc than the one it currently has.She said the UK and EU should be “way more ambitious” about reaching a full trade deal.In a speech setting out the UK’s negotiating objectives, the British prime minister said the question was whether to seek a Canadian-style deal or an Australian-style relationship, “and I have no doubt that in either case the UK will prosper”.But speaking in the European Parliament, Ms von der Leyen said both models fell short of a deal which would meet the goals of allowing trade without tariffs and quotas.That aim, set out in the political declaration, would require a “level playing field” with both sides guaranteeing “fair competition and the protection of social, environmental and consumer standards”.“We are ready to discuss all different models of trade agreement. But all these models, whatever you choose, have one thing in common — they all come not only with rights but also with obligations for both sides.”The Canada deal eliminates most, but not all, tariffs and quotas and “we still have our standards that have to be respected”, she said.Ms von der Leyen added: “Honestly, I was a little bit surprised to hear the prime minister of the United Kingdom speak about the Australian model.“Australia, without any doubt, is a strong and a like-minded partner. But the European Union does not have a trade agreement with Australia.“We are currently trading on WTO terms and, if this is the British choice, well, we are fine with that, without any question.”But the EU was trying to negotiate a trade deal with Australia to end the current situation.“Of course the UK can decide to settle for less, but I personally believe that we should be way more ambitious,” she said.Javid plansMs von der Leyen’s speech in Strasbourg came as the UK government set out further details of its plans for January 1st, 2021 after the Brexit transition period expires.Chancellor Sajid Javid said the government will aim to conclude a full range of equivalence assessments by June 2020 – allowing the UK and EU to respect each other’s rules.But he said the UK would also have the freedom to erge and regulate in a different way from the rules set in Brussels.Writing in City AM, he said: “Each side will only grant equivalence if it believes the other’s regulations are compatible.“But compatible does not mean identical, and both the UK and the EU have at different times recognised the importance of focusing on regulatory outcomes.“We will no longer be rule-takers, but we remain committed to the highest international standards of financial regulation and to shaping global rule-making.”But Brussels’ chief negotiator Michel Barnier said: “I would like to take this opportunity to make it clear to certain people in the United Kingdom bearing authority that they should not kid themselves about this – there will not be general, open-ended, ongoing equivalence in financial services.”The EU would “retain a free hand to take our own decisions”.Senior cabinet minister Michael Gove confirmed on Monday that goods coming to Britain from the EU will face import controls from January 1st.The British Retail Consortium said the government would have to move fast to get infrastructure in place for the start of 2021, warning that without adequate preparations the availability of goods on shelves would be disrupted, with fresh fruit and vegetables especially vulnerable.Mr Barnier told MEPs it would not be “business as usual” after January 1st.“Come what may, on January 1st we will be imposing checks on all products entering the single market, just as we do to every other third country in the world,” he said. – PA

title: brighton known party atmosphere untilcoronavirus washed foreign
story: Since 1981 Brighton barber Tony Wheeler has welcomed customers with open arms. But with the city declared the epicentre of Britain’s coronavirus outbreak he has in recent days been keeping his hands firmly to himself.“I have to admit I am worried about it,” says Wheeler, who yesterday was steering clear of shaking hands and leaving the haircuts to his younger members of staff despite his nickname ‘Lucky Tone’ proudly embossed on the shop mirror. “My problem is I always catch everything.” Not, he adds, that there have been many customers to even shake hands with at his barber shop on London Road. “It is killing business. People are very scared about everything and they don’t want to come out.”Brighton is normally better known for its party atmosphere and invigorating sea air, but that was before coronavirus washed up from foreign shores.Now residents are instead reaching for surgical masks and avoiding bodily contact as five of the eight confirmed cases of coronavirus in the UK are in the city.For an indication of how seriously some are taking the outbreak, a few hundred yards up the road from Wheeler’s barbers, Chinese supermarket Yun Feng Oriental Food Store yesterday had a sign displayed in the window saying it was closed for deliveries and would only accept customers wearing masks and disposable gloves – which were being made available in store.Over the road Yagmur Mete, the 22-year-old manager of an organic fruit and veg shop, was rather more relaxed, although admitted a new staff member recently arrived from Turkey had grown so concerned about the outbreak that he had just rushed into the city centre to buy himself a mask. “I told him we have always had outbreaks,” she says. “A couple of years ago it was the same with swine flu and everyone panicked then.”Some here are still treating the outbreak with similar sangfroid. In primary school playgrounds yesterday children had even invented a new game: coronavirus tag. But along the waymarks visited by the Hove scout leader and coronavirus “super spreader” Steve Walsh, a rising sense of anxiety is gripping the city.The 53-year-old Walsh called in at the pub for a drink on Saturday February 1 after picking up the disease at a Singapore conference at the end of last month and returning to Hove via a skiing holiday in the Alps. Five staff members at the pub who might have come into contact with Walsh have since been instructed to self-isolate” though yesterday afternoon a gaggle of hardened drinkers were still propping up the bar.A far more popular destination seemed the pharmacy over the road where staff said they had sold out of hand sanitiser gel and face masks. Demand is running so high that according to the pharmacy even the main warehouse in Croydon which supplies the protective masks has run out.Prior to being quarantined at an isolation unit at London's St Guy’s Hospital, Walsh also attended a yoga class at the Cornerstone Community Centre in Hove. The centre has since closed for the week with manager Jonathan Burrell (who attended the class) in self-isolation awaiting his fate.His colleague, Paul O’Connell, says he is yet to report any symptoms although will remain in isolation until next week. “On Monday morning we had a couple of children’s groups at the centre and all the parents came to take their kids out,” he says. “People have been worried and there has been a bit of panic around.”Outside the community centre, local resident Angi Drew was surveying the noticeboard for upcoming activities. But the 64-year-old admits even after it opens she will give the centre a wide berth for a while. Drew will also be avoiding the communion cup if it is passed around her church this Sunday (during the 2009 swine flu outbreak church leaders withheld the communion cup). “I imagine I am going to be very cautious,” she says.The outbreak has led to some unpleasant reports of discrimination against the city’s large Chinese community, many of whom are students.Near Brighton station 22-year-old Sussex University media student Olivia Loi was recording a film with fellow Chinese classmates - some of whom were wearing masks. She said two friends from the Philippines had in recent days had eggs thrown at them for wearing masks in Brighton.“I feel there is discrimination towards Asian people if they are wearing masks but it is just common sense,” she says.Loi, who comes from the Chinese city of Macau, also has a word of warning for those still not taking the arrival of coronavirus in Britain seriously enough.“Most people in the UK don’t know how dangerous it is,” she says. “But people should be as worried about the virus as we are because it spreads really fast.”More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: coronavirus super spreaders links schools sparks panic brighton
story: The coronavirus threat has spread to schools and prisons, with warnings from the Health Secretary that the crisis facing Britain “will get worse before it gets better”.Matt Hancock on Tuesday announced plans for hospitals to build emergency isolation facilities, saying the Government would take all necessary precautions to keep the public safe.Boris Johnson, the Prime Minister, said everyone “should be confident and calm” about Britain’s response to the virus. Four schools in Brighton were on Tuesday allowing children to stay home, or had pupils in “self-isolation” amid growing panic across the city. Four GP surgeries and a nursing home have closed as a result of links with coronavirus, with two GPs among those diagnosed in recent days.On Tuesday Steve Walsh, a Hove businessman, was identified as the man who had inadvertently passed on the virus to 11 Britons, including five Brighton residents.The father-of-two had joined friends skiing in France on his way back to the UK from a conference in Singapore.Two prisoners in HMP Bullingdon, Oxfordshire, were being tested for coronavirus on Tuesday after coming down with flu-like symptoms. One had recently been transferred from a Thai prison. Both are being kept in isolation in their cells, with restrictions placed on access to the prison wing as they await test results.Meanwhile, senior GPs claimed that NHS 111 had directed patients with flu-like symptoms to consult their GP, without checking if they had travelled from regions worst-affected by coronavirus.Those at risk of the virus are supposed to be sent to take tests in NHS isolation pods.But NHS England insisted that the protocols given to advisers ensured those from China and other countries most at risk were being directed to get help without putting other patients at risk.On Tuesday the World Health Organisation (WHO) urged countries to be “as aggressive as possible” at containing the virus, warning that it should never have been allowed to get beyond China.Director general Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said the virus was “public enemy number one,” and said every country must use every weapon in its armoury to control the virus.Health chiefs warned that it could be 18 months before a vaccine is available.On Tuesday Mr Hancock told the Commons: “The situation will get worse before it gets better. We will be guided by the science. Be in no doubt, we will do everything that is effective to tackle this virus and keep people safe.”“Today I can announce to the House the immediate launch of a capital facility to support any urgent works the NHS needs for the coronavirus response, such as the creation of further isolation areas and other necessary facilities.”Mr Hancock added that efforts to trace anyone who had been in contact with the first four UK coronavirus cases were “complete”, while work relating to the latter four, all of which were infected by Mr Walsh, was “ongoing”.On Tuesday the WHO announced a name for the virus - Covid-19.Its director general told a press conference a name was decided that “did not refer to a geographical location, an animal, an inidual or group of people, and which is also pronounceable and related to the disease”.Earlier, Professor Paul Cosford, emeritus medical director of Public Health England (PHE), said “contact tracing” run by PHE was “working very well”.He added: “I should say that the people who are of concern are those who have had very close contact with somebody with coronavirus, face-to-face contact or within a two-metre range for 15 minutes or more.”A total of 13 British people are now confirmed to have the virus - all but one linked to Mr Walsh - while a further two Chinese citizens, one of whom was a student at the University of York, are being treated in Newcastle.An NHS spokesman said: “NHS 111 does not advise patients with concerns about coronavirus to visit their GP.” More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: new hampshire primary 2020 live results latest democratic vote
story: Pete Buttigieg won the first vote of the primaries, claiming the Iowa caucus. Can he maintain momentum and win New Hampshire?Tuesday night is the second Democrat contest, in New HampshireAll polls now closed as results start to dropBernie Sanders is currently favourite to winColorado senator Michael Bennet suspends his campaignJoe Biden, fourth in Iowa, hits out at winner Pete Buttigieg Bernie Sanders is leading the New Hampshire primary with the first results dropping. The progressive senator from Vermont appears to be around six per cent ahead of his nearest rival, former South Bend, Indiana mayor Pete Buttigieg.Moderate candidate Amy Klobuchar is currently in third place, with around a fifth of the votes counted. It appears to be a very bad night for Joe Biden, the former US vice president, who is currently in fifth place. Meanwhile tech entrepreneur Andrew Yang, who campaigned on giving every adult American $1,000 a month, suspended his campaign for president Tuesday after failing to make an impact in the New Hampshire primary.Our signature proposal, universal basic income, has become part of the mainstream conversation, Mr Yang told cheering supporters as he bowed out.Expert insight and exclusive analysis on the 2020 election, written by our US team.New Hampshire is the second contest of the US presidential nominating cycle, and while few votes are on offer, it gives candidates a chance to build momentum for their campaigns in a crowded field.Bernie might be heading for victory tonight but that does not mean all his supporters think he is home a dry, Ben Riley-Smith writes. Daniel Perea-Kane, a 25-year-old teacher who has been knocking doors for the Sanders campaign in the state, has worries about what comes next. He believes Pete Buttigieg and Michael Bloomberg are not out of the race yet, seeing them as the key moderates to beat. But that is not his real fear. I'm more concerned with the party, he tells The . I think they'll take any measure they can to stop him taking the leadership.If it seems like Bernie is winning a lot they might try to create enough opposition to give it to someone else at the convention. Others are more optimistic. Ian Root, a 38-year-old software engineer and campaign volunteer, thinks his candidate can defeat Donald Trump. I think when people have Bernie and Trump on stage the authenticity Bernie brings will ring true and also the policy knowledge, Ian says. He dismisses the idea that the only way to win back supporters who went for the US president in 2016 is with a centrist. I think it's nonsense, he says. People talk about moderates as though it is people with opinions all down the middle.If you can find the right unifying issue then you can pull them to you, even if that policy is quite extreme. Joe Biden's surrogates are doing their best to mask a disappointing night for the absent candidate at his campaign's New Hampshire watch party.Mr Biden originally planned to attend, but his campaign announced on Tuesday that that he would instead hold an event in South Carolina.That left former New Hampshire Governor John Lynch and Mr Biden's sister, Valerie Biden Owens, to take his place.Ms Biden Owens said this was the very beginning of a long marathon to the nomination. And we're ready to go the distance.While the results don't seem to be what we hoped, we're going to take our campaign to every corner of this country, she said.Appearing to the audience via live stream, Mr Biden vowed to return to defeat Mr Trump in November's general election.I do love New Hampshire, Mr Biden said. And I mean it.Mr Steyer's press secretary has insisted the candidate is just getting started amid reports the billionaire was about to end his campaign. Just as we saw in Iowa last week, tonight’s results from New Hampshire show that the race for the Democratic nomination is wide open. Until Nevada and South Carolina have the chance to vote, we won’t know which candidates can build the erse and unified coalition we need to win in November.Mr Steyer has currently got just 3.6 per cent in New Hampshire, but he has set his sights on South Carolina and Nevada where he has spending huge sums on advertising. South Carolina, the fourth state to vote, will offer the first indication of how candidates fare with African American voters. Mr Biden has hitched his campaign's success to winning the state, but Mr Steyer is closing in on him in the polls.Progressive candidate Mr Sanders has maintained his lead in the primary with almost half of the votes counted, with a four point margin over moderate Mr Buttigieg, who has received 23.4 per cent of the vote share. Another moderate, Ms Klobuchar, has had a strong night with almost 20 per cent of the vote share. It is a poor night for Ms Warren, who represents neighbouring Massachusetts in the US senate. She is currently on just 9.5 per cent - ahead of Mr Biden who is currently in fifth place with 8.6 per cent. The New Hampshire primary has claimed a second scalp with Michael Bennet announcing he is dropping out of the race tonight. The Colorado senator was a late entrant to the race and had staked his bid largely on trying to win New Hampshire.  Once tipped to be a rising star by Barack Obama, Mr Bennet ran on a centrist platform but ultimately struggled to break out of the crowded field. The 55-year-old told supporters shortly after polls closed in New Hampshire that it was fitting to end his presidential effort in the state, where he had actively campaigned.Elizabeth Warren is addressing supporters with early results showing her in fourth place in New Hampshire. Despite the poor performance, the Massachusetts senator insists her campaign is in it for the long haul. We are just getting started, she says. Ms Warren conceded that Mr Sanders and Mr Buttigieg had strong nights. But she added: I also want to congratulate my friend and colleague Amy Klobuchar for showing just how wrong the pundits can be when they count a woman out. Ms Warren has previously claimed Mr Sanders told her a woman could not win the White House.The senator also warned that Democrats have to be honest with themselves, saying: we might be headed for another one of those long primary fights that lasts for months.Framing herself as the unity candidate, Ms Warren said: The fight between factions in our party has taken a sharp turn in recent weeks, with ads mocking other candidates and with supporters of some candidates shouting curses  about other Democratic candidates. But if we’re going to beat Donald Trump in November, we are going to need huge turnout within our party, and to get that turnout, we will need a nominee that the broadest coalition of our party feels they can get behind.In case you missed the Andrew Yang phenomenon here is Nick Allen's interview with him in September.  Mr Yang explained how he wanted to give $1,000 a month to every American adult, much of it funded by taxing large businesses like Amazon, Google and Facebook.  I'm peeling off Trump supporters,” Mr Yang told The  . “There were many people who voted for Donald Trump because they believed his solutions, but his solutions were garbage and nonsense.Our signature proposal, universal basic income, has become part of the mainstream conversation, Mr Yang told cheering supporters as he bowed out tonight.The 45-year-old was polling at a lowly three per cent with 20 percent of polling stations reporting, placing him well out of contention.Without a doubt, we accelerated the eradication of poverty in our society by years, even generations, Mr Yang added.Ben Riley-Smith, our US editor, has this: Hello from what is effectively Bernie HQ tonight - a vast sports hall in Manchester, New Hampshire.  It is still only just filling up but those already sitting on the bleachers are expecting a mighty night. Whoops, cheering and chants of Bernie! Bernie! rung out as the clock turned just past 8pm, the moment all the state's polls closed. We still have a long night ahead, but the lead Mr Sanders has on his nearest rival, Pete Buttigieg, is substantial.  A double first for Bernie - tied top in Iowa and then winning here - would mean he is most likely to take the Demcratic nomination.  Imagine a Trump-Bernie battle? The electoral map scrambled, two fired-up septuagenarians going toe-to-toe. Is that where we're heading?All polls are now closed in the Granite State. Around 14 per cent of the votes are now in and we'll be bringing you the remaining results as they arrive.We are hearing that Andrew Yang, the maverick outside candidate who surprised everyone to make the national debate stage, is planning to suspend his campaign tonight. Sources say that the disappointing early results in New Hampshire are behind the decision. If the reports are true, Mr Yang's departure will further diminish the ersity of the candidate field.The Republican primary is also being held in the Granite State today, but since Mr Trump does not have any serious competition it has gone largely unreported. However Mr Trump, who was campaigning in New Hampshire on Monday night, has sought to inject chaos in the process.The Republican president suggested that conservative-leaning voters could affect the state's Democratic primary results, saying: I hear a lot of Republicans tomorrow will vote for the weakest candidate possible of the Democrats.My only problem is I'm trying to figure out who is their weakest candidate. I think they're all weak, he added.There is one problem with this tactic: it is only registered Democrats and independent voters who can participate in New Hampshire's Democratic presidential primary.We have an early estimate from voting wards in Concord and Dover, New Hampshire, which show Bernie Sanders ahead. Pete Buttigieg is in second place. Here is CNN's estimates at this early stage:The first polls have closed in New Hampshire. Early exit polls show the majority of voters were undecided until very recently. By the night's end, New Hampshire could begin culling the crowded Democratic field, which still features nearly a dozen candidates battling for the chance to take on Donald Trump in November.This ballot box dates back to 1888Roughly 6 in 10 people said they prioritise a candidate who can beat Donald Trump over one who agrees with them on the issues, an exit poll found. Just over 1 in 10 voters said they were very confident that their party's process for choosing a presidential nominee was fair, according to a wide-ranging AP VoteCast survey. At the same time, nearly 8 in 10 also viewed the economy as unfair, although there was little consensus on which candidate would do the best job of stewarding the world's largest economy. Most polls close at 7pm but a few remain open until 8pmMr Biden will be absent from his campaign's results night party in New Hampshire tonight. The former vice president will instead be in South Carolina, the state he has staked his campaign's survival on. But his campaign has acknowledged Mr Biden needs a strong finish tonight if he is to remain in contention in the next phase of the race. I spoke to some of the surrogates driving his campaign in the Granite State earlier this week. Have a read here.This from David Millward in New England:Politico has been leaked a memo from Unite the Country, a super Pac backing Joe Biden, warning of a split convention with Bernie Sanders squaring off against Mike Bloomberg - the billionaire former New York mayor who, despite having already reportedly spent more than $300 million on advertising, decided against setting foot in Iowa or New Hampshire.Pleading with donors to stay loyal to Mr Biden, Larry Rasky, the Pac treasurer wrote: “Donors hedging their bets on Biden because of Bloomberg could be creating a doomsday scenario for Democrats everywhere. “The Sanders-Warren wing of the Party is ready for the Bloomberg fight. Democrats cannot afford a split Convention.It's a sign of increasing desperation in the Biden campaign, which is bracing itself for another bad result in New Hampshire.Mr Biden has already cut his losses and has headed off to South Carolina where, at least according to the latest polls, he still enjoys a healthy lead over his rivals.Despite leaving New Hampshire for South Carolina, Joe Biden is still asking for late donations in the “Granite State”. He just sent out this email:“As I write this email to you today, New Hampshire is voting in our country’s very first primary. “My team tells me we need another $120,000 before 8pm in order to fully execute our Get Out The Vote efforts in the Granite State. “Will you be the one to push us over the top? Pitch in $5”Nick Allen is at a polling station in the quiet rural town of Henniker.It's not a record turn out here. There have been 1,276 votes so far in the Democrat and Republican primaries combined, according to the machine that counts the votes in a polling station at the local school. About 70 per cent of the votes are in the Democrat primary. The election moderator says the turnout is about average.Outside, Rod Pimentel was standing with an Amy Klobuchar sign. He said: I'm a progressive, I like everything Bernie and Warren have to say. But we need somebody at the top of the ticket who can reach out. I'd like to see Amy with a running mate from the left of the party. We can't go into this ided. His friend Scott Osgood, 67, was encouraging people to vote for Elizabeth Warren. He said: She's got all the best plans, real plans. I think she'll do good today, good would be the top three. I met Amy too, and that would be OK.Bernie Sanders and his wife, Jane, greet people campaigning for him outside a polling station  Mr Sanders and his wife, Jane, greeted people campaigning for him outside a polling station in New Hampshire.Michael Bloomberg is the elephant in the room in New Hampshire. His shadow over the Democratic race lengthened today after the billionaire former New York mayor was the surprise winner in Dixville Notch, a hamlet that traditionally votes first in New Hampshire's primary.Mr Bloomberg has taken an unorthodox approach to the race, opting to skip the first four states to vote and focusing all of his energy in the larger, bigger prize states.  He is not on the ballot in New Hampshire, however residents of Dixville Notch opted to write his name in, resulting in him receiving three of the five votes cast after the stroke of midnight.The ritual in Dixville Notch, dating back six decades, gives a candidate brief bragging rights, as state law does not require polls to even open until 11 am.Bloomberg's campaign was quick to seize the moment.We're not competing in NH, but Mike still wins Dixville Notch, his campaign said.While the number of ballots cast there is tiny in the context of the full-state Democratic primary, which drew almost 250,000 voters in 2016, the victor in Dixville Notch has gone on to win two-thirds of the contested major party primaries in the state.Ben Riley-Smith on the reaction 'Mayor Pete' gets from some of his supportersThe nation has comedy show Saturday Night Live to thank for dubbing Pete Buttigieg, the former South Bend mayor picking up support, the White Obama. That nickname was going viral over the weekend after it was used in a skit the show did on the Democratic presidential debates. But it is a comparison I found being made by some voters at Buttigieg events back in December when I saw him on the Iowa stump for this magazine profile.Pete Buttigieg greets supporters outside a polling station in Nashua, New HampshireIt also appears to be something Joe Biden, his moderate rival, is concerned about. This guy’s not Barack Obama, Mr Biden said recently. Mr Buttigieg shot back: “Well, he's right. I'm not, and neither is he. Mr Obama aside, it is clear that some of Mr Buttigieg's most ardent supporters do see him as embodying a similar sense of hope and optimism. That was true at the campaign event he did in a university hall on Monday morning in the New Hampshire town of Plymouth. Charlene Joyce, 64, stood up at the end of questions before Mr Buttigieg left and declared “I have never, ever felt as energised by anybody as I am by Mayor Pete.She said he was bringing “grace and dignity back to American politics and then started signing 'the sun will come up tomorrow. Ms Joyce told The Daily  afterwards: This is a time when we really need kindness in this country. I think Donald Trump has turned us from one of the most powerful countries in the world to a laughing stock.”Another Mayor Petet superfan, 89-year-old Pat Provencher, was covered in Buttigieg badges. She had seen Mr Buttigieg speak in the state in April 2018 and had been supporting him ever since. He has far exceeded our expectations, she said. This is a time when we really need kindness in this country.“I think Donald Trump has turned us from one of the most powerful countries in the world to a laughing stock.”Nick Allen, on the ground in New Hampshire, is picking up strong support for the US senator...She's the funniest candidate in the race. Regardless of their politics, or choice of candidate, New Hampshire voters have been leaving Klobuchar rallies with a smile on their face.Ms Klobuchar's anecdotes include how her first campaign slogan was All the way with Amy K, which she doesn't use any more after realising the connotations.Her zingers include a Sarah Palin-esque one about how she can see Canada from my porch in Minnesota.She also talks emotionally about her roots, including her miner grandfather.The crowds have been getting bigger, and late tracking polls had her in third place behind Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigieg.Ms Klobuchar is something of an open book as politicians go, and it is clear the wave of support for Mr Buttigieg has annoyed her.While he has been a small town mayor she has passed over 100 bills in the US senate, and won every election she's ever fought, including in Republican areas.Amy Klobuchar on the campaign trail todayI was really impressed with her and I wasn't expecting to be, said voter Marie Lee, 77, who was wearing a Pete sticker at Ms Klobuchar's event, and may change allegiance.She' s got the experience that Pete lacks. She's been challenged, she added.Joe Foster, the former attorney general of New Hampshire, who's endorsement is sought after by candidates, said he was backing Ms Klobuchar.She's a rare talent. I've seen a lot of presidential candidates. They all have charisma, but she has an ability to connect with people I haven't seen in a long time. I saw it with Bill Clinton, it's a gift. She's smart, she's tough, and she speaks from the heart. Ms Klobcuhar appeared confident as she visited a polling station today.Ben Riley-Smith with the significance of tonight's vote for the leading hopefulsIf the 78-year-old can win again in New Hampshire, as he did four years ago, Mr Sanders will be the front-runner and America will be a big step closer to having a democratic socialist presidential nominee. A political unknown this time last year, Mr Buttigieg, 38, will want to build on a joint-first finish in Iowa. Coming in the top two here will give him a chance of boosting support when the race goes national on Super TuesdayThe former US vice president is expected to have another difficult night. If he comes fourth again - or even fifth? - his campaign will be fully on the rocks, given he has been the front-runner practically since the 2016 election result. The left-wing Massachusetts senator actually did well in Iowa, getting just 6 percent points fewer votes than Mr Sanders and Mr Buttigieg in the second round. But with fellow progressive Mr Sanders dominating she needs to break beyond him somehow. Three months ago few would have predicted the moderate Minnesota senator would have performed this strongly. She came fifth in Iowa and is third in some New Hampshire polls. If she beats Mr Biden here she can claim momentum is building. Only slightly more Democrats voted in Iowa's caucuses last week than in 2016 - and that has party operatives worried about voter enthusiasm going into November.Will New Hampshire's Democratic voters surge to the polls or also stay home?New Hampshire's secretary of state has predicted a healthy 292,000 Democratic voters, which would be about 40,000 more than voted in 2016.As Democratic presidential candidates canvass the state, Nolan Pelletier wears a cape of stars and stripes for a haircut on his 10th birthday at the Parliament Barber Shop in Manchester, NHThe turnout question hangs heavily over the field for two reasons.The start of Democratic voting in the long primary season coincides with a rise in anxiety among that party's voters about the presidential election and an increase in confidence among Republicans. Low turnout would be a sign of Democratic weakness at the ballot box, at least for now.Second, the candidacy of Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders is premised on the theory that his ultra-liberal platform will turn out new voters, but that didn't happen in Iowa. Whether more voters cast ballots in New Hampshire may carry big implications for Sanders' argument.Nick Allen has been speaking to Bernie Sanders' team.Ben Cohen, co-founder of Ben &amp Jerry’s ice cream, who has been campaigning for Mr Sanders, told The :“l saw Pete’s got a new ad out, well produced ad. A lot of people just see the ads. You can come up with great ads but Bernie’s been fighting for justice for 40 years.” Without naming names Mr Cohen said other candidates had been saying nice things for three to six months while Mr Sanders had been pursuing his agenda for decades.People could vote for a candidate funded by Wall Street and corporations, or a candidate funded by millions of Americans being screwed by Wall Street and corporations.Habiba Choudhury, 28, a Sanders volunteer who came from New York to knock doors, told The  the media appeared to be backing Mr Buttigieg,and that wasn't helping Mr Sanders.I think the media focus on Buttigieg is affecting it. They say there’s no bias in the media but there is.As votes are counted in New Hampshire, Joe Biden is shifting ahead to South Carolina, where success is critical to his campaign.Mr Biden's Democratic presidential campaign says he and his wife, Dr. Jill Biden, will travel to Columbia on Tuesday night for a launch party.South Carolina is key to Biden&#39s successRep. Cedric Richmond is Mr Biden's campaign co-chairman and had already been planning to attend the event.The campaign says Mr Biden will address supporters in New Hampshire via livestream while his sister, Valerie Biden Owens, will thank them in person.Mr Biden has a lot at stake in South Carolina, where he has led polling and has long relationships with the heavily black electorate. But other candidates including Bernie Sanders and billionaire Tom Steyer have been campaigning hard in the state.Mr Biden says in a release he plans to travel later in the week to Nevada, which holds its caucus vote later this month.Ben Riley-Smith, our US Editor, has this from snowy Henniker, New Hampshire:It is easy to read too much into the number of people who turn up to some candidates' campaign events and not others. Their voters may be less available, like working parents. The events could just be at tricky times of day or especially remote locations. But with that said, the numbers that Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigieg have been drawing in over the last few days in New Hampshire is telling. Mr Sanders, the left-wing Vermont senator, on Monday night held an eve of poll rally that attracted more than 7,500 people at the Whittemore Center Arena in Durham, New Hampshire. Yes, a lot of them were nearby students and, yes, the allure of the US rock band The Strokes may have played a role. But there was huge energy in the room. Mr Buttigieg, the former South Bend mayor, has not hit those numbers but over the weekend he held a succession of events which drew in more than a thousand people. That has dwarfed the efforts of other candidates like Joe Biden, the former US vice president. His flagging campaign has seen meetings in gym halls with only a few hundred voters. It all points to a critical factor in these races - enthusiasm. It is the lifeblood of campaigns, convincing people to both get involved, knocking doors and making calls, and also turn out to vote. The evidence is, in New Hampshire at least, Mr Sanders and Mr Buttigieg are enthusing their supporters and Mr BIden is not.My colleague David Millward put $5 on Mayor Pete to win the Democrat nomination a year ago.He's now feeling pretty pleased with himself...Buttigieg fans in New Hampshire on February 9Quite simply, the more people see of Pete Buttigieg, the more they like him – and so do party donors. He raised $24.7 million in the final quarter of 2019 with 326,000 people chipping in. Significantly Buttigieg, who served in Afghanistan, has the backing of VoteVets, a political action committee backing liberal veterans for public office.Contrast that with Joe Biden, who was seen as the likeliest standard-bearer of the establishment wing of the Democratic party. His campaign has, to put it mildly, been disastrous.Nick Allen reports from New Hampshire:It's a big responsibility being a primary voter in New Hampshire. Along with their compatriots in Iowa those who want to can see, even meet, all the candidates and size them up personally. It's their role to kick the tyres on behalf of the nation, and see if the politicians are up to the job.And they are famed for getting all the information they can - and then deciding late.A child holds a sign supporting Pete Buttigieg, at a rally in Portsmouth, NHAfter seeing Pete Buttigieg making a passionate appeal for votes at a campaign stop, Donna Salviati, 58, a local teacher, was still unsure.He was exciting...but I’m not ready to choose. Pete’s made it into my top three. I’m not telling you who the others are. “I know what my top three issues are. One of those is the opioid crisis. Now, I’m going to have to go back home, look again at what they’ve all said about those issues, read their websites, and newspaper editorials about them. Then I’ll make my choice.Elizabeth Warren says anyone looking for contrasts between her and fellow progressive Bernie Sanders can find them.The Massachusetts senator is stopping at polling stations across New Hampshire on Tuesday to greet people voting in the state's primary.Elizabeth Warren in Manchester, NH, on February 8Asked if she'd done enough to differentiate herself from Mr Sanders, Ms Warren said there were key differences that were obvious to voters.Ms Warren says she doesn't want to denigrate Mr Sanders but says she has a deep political record of accomplishments, including helping to create a federal agency to protect consumers during the Obama administration.Both Ms Warren and Mr Sanders have been careful not to criticise each other harshly for months as they compete in the Democratic presidential primary.Elizabeth Warren offers donuts to supporters at a polling site in New HampshireNear a polling station at Portsmouth Middle School, Ms Warren handed out doughnuts to supporters and spoke to a man on a bike, even using his cellphone to urge his daughter to vote.Asked if she had any advice for those heading to the polls, Ms Warren quipped:Vote for me.Minnesota Senator Amy Klobuchar has visited two polling places in New Hampshire's largest city on primary day.She's savouring what she calls her landslide win in two tiny northern communities that voted just after midnight.Ms Klobuchar said in Manchester on Tuesday she was feeling good and had just met a lot of people who voted for her.Amy Klobuchar, pictured during the February 7 debate in Manchester, NHShe says she feels good about those early results in those gigantic voting locations up there.Ms Klobuchar won the Democratic primary in Hart's Location with six votes and in Millsfield with two. But former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg won Dixville Notch with two write-in votes.Ms Klobuchar says Bloomberg needs to be on the debate stage and then she can be on equal footing with him.She says she's never going to beat the billionaire on the airwaves but can beat him on the debate stage.Sanders, 78, is forecasted to win an average of 28 per cent of the vote in New Hampshire, according to FiveThirtyEight's analysis. In 80 per cent of simulations, he wins between 20 and 36 per cent of the vote.He has a 2 in 3 chance of winning the most votes, much better than the second most likely winner, Buttigieg, who has a 3 in 10 chance.Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders is the favourite to win tonight&#39s pollJoe Biden is portraying himself as an underdog in Tuesday's New Hampshire primary.The former vice president noted on MSNBC's Morning Joe that Bernie Sanders of Vermont won New Hampshire by 20 percentage points in 2016 and has a next-door neighbor advantage and real enthusiasm going for him.But Mr Biden says Mr Sanders' label as a democratic socialist will not be helpful in the South and other places.Mr Biden says I think I'm an underdog here in New Hampshire but he still feels good and is in the race for the long haul.Joe Biden is not expected to win New HampshireMr Biden says their party's 2020 presidential nominee will need significant support from African Americans as well as keeping working-class white folks, two areas the former vice president sees as his strength.If you can't win in Pennsylvania, if you can't help win Senate seats in North Carolina and Georgia, then it's going to be awful hard to beat President Donald Trump.Mr Biden also took a swipe at billionaires Tom Steyer and Michael Bloomberg for the hundreds of millions of dollars he says they've spent on TV advertising.Mr Biden says he's looking forward to debating Mr Bloomberg because he can't compete with his money.Asked about polling suggesting Bloomberg is cutting into Biden's support among moderate Americans, Mr Biden says:It's amazing what $500 million can do.Good morning, and welcome to our coverage of tonight's second contest in the race for the Democrat nomination- the New Hampshire primary.Only twice since 1972 have Democrats ultimately chosen a nominee who did not win either Iowa or New Hampshire. Good news for Pete Buttigieg, who won Iowa - but what about the others?Coronavirus latest news: Japan cruise ship has 39 new cases, including quarantine officerDavid Hockney&#39s The Splash sells at Sotheby&#39s for more than £23 millionMichel Barnier tells Sajid Javid not to &#39kid&#39 himself over long-term financial services deal with EUArmy hits recruitment target for first time in six years Britain&#39s economy will be hardest hit in Europe by climate change, study finds Row erupts at General Synod over LGBT rights in the churchSocial media sites could be blocked from UK, as Ofcom gets job of  policing duty of care lawsCabinet reshuffle: Remainers back in favour, but Boris Johnson steers clear of top table &#39revolution&#39Coronavirus threat spreads to British schools and prisons Teenager who came into contact with coronavirus superspreader targeted with abuse BBC Chairman says scrapping licence fee would &#39weaken the nation&#39London-based security expert faces fresh call from US to give evidence to Russian election interference probeComment: With HS2, Boris has rediscovered the can-do spirit of the VictoriansComment: HS2 and quicker, local projects will transform the way people travelThe carnage in Syria&#39s Idlib should not come as a surprise to anyoneRussian bride and groom face jail over wedding pictures featuring spyCoronavirus threat reaches schools as UK warned crisis &#39will get worse before it gets better&#39British man, 55, in hospital after beating with ski pole as police hunt for snowboarder suspect in AustriaWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: cycle to work bike cycling london 2020 environment
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘At best, I’ll get fit, rediscover a long-lost hobby and do my bit to tackle the growing climate crisis. At worst, I’ll end up with a broken leg and a wardrobe full of Lycra’, says Will KirbyOut-and-out epiphanies are rare occurrences, but as I stood with my face deeply embedded in the armpit of a complete stranger in the early hours of the morning for the third time that week, I had the strangest feeling that I was, in fact, done with commuting on the Tube.There were other signs of course – like being kneecapped by the men in suits desperate to get onto the train before anyone has got off, or the passive-aggressive call to ‘move down please!’ at every stop as I consider how I could possibly make all 6ft of myself any smaller to allow for more space, or the unrecognisable smells that could honestly be anything from last night’s takeaway to this morning’s missed shower, or being late because of another series of red signals, or the 37 suitcases I had to negotiate because someone’s decided to move house, or looking at my bank balance and realising these joys are costing me more than £40 a week. I don’t know. But whatever it was, I realised then and there that I needed to find another way to get to work.&nbspSo I did some investigating. A commute can make or break your day so it’s important to get it right. Walking was an option (healthy, free) but would have taken almost two hours each way, which would mean spending more than 12 hours a day either going from, to, or being at the office. I could jog, but, sadly, I hate jogging. The bus is doable, and a cheaper option than the Tube, but would involve three separate buses that aren’t very reliable. Which leaves me with one option. The bike.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSeven things no-one tells you when you start cycling to workInitially I wasn’t sure whether I wanted to join the fluorescent, Lycra-clad hordes that zoom around the capital at breakneck speeds. I’d never really ridden a road bike before, let alone had an argument with a car or a bus about who’s on whose side of the road. How was I going to fit in if I’d never even owned a pair of mirrored sunglasses and didn’t really know what Strava was?! But it didn’t take long to realise that there are some massive benefits that outweigh any nerves or doubts about taking to the road on two wheels.Firstly, it’s healthy. Even a short cycle at the start and end of the day is exercise you probably wouldn’t otherwise have done, and it makes so much more sense to combine your fitness with your commute rather than trying to carve a slice out of your day to go to the gym. It also makes you feel good – if you take a look around the office first thing in the morning, it’s easy to spot the bright faces who’ve biked into work in amongst those who spent at least part of their morning under the ground.&nbspIt is also better for the environment. Public transport, for its many faults (see above), is certainly greener than driving myself to work every morning, but there’s only so long you can tell yourself it doesn’t have a carbon footprint. Transport for London uses more electricity than anything else in the city, consuming enough power to fuel around 360,000 homes each year. By ditching my Oyster, I can hopefully shed with it that last ounce of green guilt.&nbspWhy I've pledged to go flight-free for a yearWhy I'm going vegan for 2020This year I pledge to buy local and eat with the seasonsAnd I may as well do what I can to reduce pollution in the city where I live, even if it is on an inidual scale. A recent study found the capital’s poor air quality leads to around 1,000 hospital admissions for asthma and serious lung conditions every year, and another revealed that around four Londoners are hospitalised every day due to asthma caused by air pollution. Breathing London air is like smoking 160 cigarettes a year, according to the British Heart Foundation, and when you then consider that pollution on the Tube is around 15 times worse than above ground, it’s got to be a good idea to spend as little time down there as you can.&nbspThe combination of a bit of light exercise and avoiding the toxic fumes that swirl around beneath the capital also reduces the chance of a heart attack and other cardiovascular diseases. In fact, if the same number of trips were made by bike as they are in Denmark (26 per cent of all trips that are less than 5km), it could save the NHS a staggering £17 billion within 20 years.So, I’m going to give it a go. At best, I’ll get fit, rediscover a long-lost hobby and do my bit to tackle the growing climate crisis. At worst, I’ll end up with a broken leg and a wardrobe full of Lycra. I’ll keep you posted.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: sport football environment impact away games flying planes
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Mainstream sport has a hugely negative impact on the world around us, yet extreme sports aim to bring us together as one with nature. It's time to start asking what the sporting world can do to prevent global warmingIn 2020 The Independent will be doing more than ever before to try and make the world a better place. When it comes to sport, that’s easier said than done.Sport is our escape, a way to block out the realities of everyday life for 90 minutes, or a few hours, maybe even an entire day. It is supposed to be enjoyed even in defeat, and yet not even sport is exempt from the greatest threat to humankind today: global warming and the negative impact of climate change.But not even sport can continue to ignore the perils that will come to threaten its very existence unless something is done to change the path it is on. After all, how will our children and grandchildren play football, rugby or cricket if there are no parks left, or will the next Lewis Hamilton be uncovered if we can’t find a sustainable way to maintain motorsport without the use of oil, petrol and even electricity?Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThis year we will be delving into how sport affects the surrounding environment, exposing the shocking truths of how it is damaging the world as we know it and highlighting the ways people are trying to bring change for the better.Why will we be doing this? Whether your outlook on global warming is akin to Greta Thunberg or Donald Trump, the truth is that sport has one of the biggest impacts on climate change. Whether it’s the Arsenal squad using a private jet to fly to Norwich, or single-use plastic being used at just about every stadium across the globe, there are endless examples of ignorance when it comes to helping the environment.There will be positives, too. What is Formula E doing to inspire change not just in motorsport but in our everyday commute? What inspired Forest Green Rovers to become the world’s first 100 per cent vegan football club? And are extreme adrenaline sports the answer – they tend to go hand in hand with being at one with the world around us in an effort not to damage it.And if we are to cover all areas of this subject, we will have to take a close look at ourselves too: the media. Is it right that journalists travel all year round aboard the most environmentally damaging transport available in automotive vehicles and aeroplanes, throwing away countless notebooks instead of recycling? If we are to ask the difficult questions, we have to be prepared to answer them too.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Alli apologised for the Snapchat post in a video on the Chinese social media platform Weibo on SundayThe Football Association has written to Tottenham midfielder Dele Alli to seek his observations about a social media post in which he appeared to joke about the coronavirus.The England player, 23, has been contacted concerning a Snapchat video he posted on Saturday. In it, he joked about the virus outbreak and appeared to mock an Asian man. The coronavirus has so far claimed the lives of over 900 people in mainland China, according to official figures.Alli apologised for the Snapchat post in a video on the Chinese social media platform Weibo on Sunday.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“Hi guys, it’s Dele I just wanted to apologise on my behalf for the video I posted on Snapchat yesterday,” he said. “It wasn’t funny and I realised that immediately and took it down. I let myself down and the club.“I don’t want you to have that impression of me because it wasn’t funny and I realised that straight away and took it down. It isn’t something that should be joked about. I’m sending all my love and all my thoughts and prayers to everyone in China.”The FA’s guidelines around media comments and social media posts remind participants that it will consider charges under Rule E3 if it is felt that someone has acted in an improper manner or brings the game into disrepute.It would be considered an aggravated breach if a comment or social media post, whether explicitly or implicitly, makes reference to ethnic origin, colour, race, nationality, religion or belief, gender, gender reassignment, sexual orientation or disability.The latest football headlines direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'It’s like discovering a new world'Scientists have discovered an asteroid with such a strange surface that they have named it the golf ball.The rock is the most heavily cratered object ever to be seen in the asteroid belt and is like discovering a new world, according to the researchers who found it. And in addition to the strange holes, it also has a mysterious bright spot on its surface.It is also quite large: the rock, known as Pallas, is the third-biggest object in the asteroid belt, and about a seventh the size of our moon. It was first discovered in 1802, but many of its details have remained mysterious.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesNow scientists have revealed the holey surface of the asteroid in images for the first time – and suggest they could also help solve some of the other mysteries about the object.Over the centuries since it was discovered, astronomers noted that Pallas takes a strange route through the asteroid belt, following a tilted journey when compared with most of the other objects that surround it.Created with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. As it moves around the Sun, it has to smash its way through to take its lonely course. Because it comes at an angle, the collisions are especially damaging, leaving the cratered service that has now been revealed in the images.“Pallas’&nbsporbit implies very high-velocity impacts,” says&nbspMichaël&nbspMarsset, the paper’s lead author said in a statement.Asteroid that ended dinosaurs acidified ocean causing mass extinction“From these images, we can now say that&nbspPallas&nbspis the most cratered object that we know of in the asteroid belt. It’s like discovering a new world.”The scientists also found one huge crater on the object's surface, which is thought to be about 400 kilometres wide. Research suggests that such a large basin would probably have been caused about 1.7 billion years ago, when Pallas was thought to be hit by an object between 20 and 40 kilometres wide, which would have thrown the pieces out into space.As well as the huge variety of holes, Pallas also has a bright spot in its surface, researchers discovered while examining the object.Scientists don't know where that is coming from. The most likely theory is that it is a huge chunk of salt, which may have been exposed after one of its collisions.People have proposed missions to Pallas with very small, cheap satellites, Marsset says. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Data could be transmitted a thousand times faster than current internet cables after a major breakthrough, scientists have said.The new research uses&nbspterahertz quantum cascade lasers that could send data around the world at speeds unimaginable using current technology.The lasers could be used to vastly speed up data communications, according to the researchers behind the study, which is published today in the journal&nbspNature Communications.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe study saw researchers make a breakthrough in the control of&nbspterahertz quantum cascade lasers, which they say could be used to transmit data at a speed of 100 gigabits. Current – very fast – ethernet connections work at 100 megabits a second, a thousand times less quick.The specific kind of lasers are different because they send out light in the terahertz&nbsprange of the electromagnetic spectrum, which is largely used to analyse chemicals. But by turning them to use to send data, they could provide much faster connections for research facilities, hospitals, satellite communications or any other situations where very fast network connections are required.Created with Sketch.Gadget and tech news: In pictures Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.125 Gun-toting humanoid robot sent into spaceRussia has launched a humanoid robot into space on a rocket bound for the International Space Station (ISS). times every second. That requires precise control, and engineers have so far been unable to do it.This is life under the longest internet shutdown in historyNow researchers think they have found a way of controlling that very fast modulation, using sound and light.This is exciting research,&nbspsaid John Cunningham, Professor of Nanoelectronics at Leeds. At the moment, the system for modulating a quantum cascade laser is electrically driven - but that system has limitations.Ironically, the same electronics that delivers the modulation usually puts a brake on the speed of the modulation. The mechanism we are developing relies instead on acoustic waves.When an electron passes through the optical part of the laser, it travels through a host of quantum wells that throw out a pulse of light energy. An electron can emit a number of those photons, and that is controlled – using soundwaves&nbspto vibrate those quantum wells – in the new experiment.Essentially, what we did was use the acoustic wave to shake the intricate electronic states inside the quantum cascade laser, said&nbspTony Kent, Professor of Physics at Nottingham. We could then see that its&nbspterahertz&nbsplight output was being altered by the acoustic wave.The research is not perfect, and more control is still needed before the lasers could be used reliably to transmit data. But with further work they could lead to major breakthroughs in transmitting data.We did not reach a situation where we could stop and start the flow completely, but we were able to control the light output by a few percent, which is a great start, said Professor Cunningham.We believe that with further refinement, we will be able to develop a new mechanism for complete control of the photon emissions from the laser, and perhaps even integrate structures generating sound with the terahertz laser, so that no external sound source is needed.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The broadcaster's flagship channel struggles&nbspamid destructive weather: 'Causing us some problems'BBC One went off-air for more than seven minutes on Sunday morning due to interference by Storm Ciara.&nbspThe BBC's flagship channel, which at the time was broadcasting Nicky Campbell's&nbspThe Big Questions, began to glitch at 11.02am before dropping off completely a minute later.&nbspThis is BBC One, I'm sorry but due to technical problems we've lost contact with The Big Questions studio in Salford, an announcer said shortly afterwards.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesInstead of moving images, the broadcast played&nbspsmooth jazz music alongside a message which read: We are sorry for the break in this programme and are trying to correct the fault.She later added: It seems that the stormy conditions up in Salford are causing us some problems. We are working as hard as we can against the weather to get back to Big Questions and Nicky in Salford as quickly&nbspas we can.At 11.08am, the announcer said the channel had solved the issue and thanked&nbspviewers for bearing with us, resulting in&nbspa failed attempt to return the broadcast to TV screens.Unfortunately we're not able to go back to Big Questions in Salford,&nbspbut please do bear with us one second, while we figure out what we're gonna do this morning, she then apologised.It was not until 11.10am that footage returned as normal.&nbspThe unusual interruption came amid travel chaos inflicted by Ciara, which is the worst storm to strike&nbspBritain in seven years.&nbspTrains, flights and ferries have been cancelled and severe weather warnings issued as&nbspCiara was forecast to pummel the UK with winds of up to 80mph.Created with Sketch. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The numbers were even worse than 2018The 92nd Academy Awards&nbspceremony had the lowest audience figures in the show’s history, US broadcaster ABC has revealed.Drawing an average of just 23.6m viewers across the night, the somewhat uneventful ceremony reached substantially fewer people&nbspthan the&nbspprevious low-point in 2018 (26.5m viewers).When&nbspthe whole of the last decade is taken into account, the decline becomes even more stark. In 2014, the Oscars managed to snare over 40m US-based viewers, nearly double this year’s count.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMany are speculating about the reasons for this year’s poor television ratings.&nbspIt’s&nbsppossible that more people are choosing to watch the Oscars illegally, via&nbspinternet&nbspstreaming sites.Created with Sketch.Oscars 2020 in pictures Show all 65Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Bong Joon Ho, right, reacts as he is presented with the award for best picture for Parasite from presenter Jane Fonda at the Oscars on Sunday, Feb. 9, 2020, at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘The jawbone was an absolutely stunning find,’ says dinosaur enthusiast who found fossil on hikeA new species of tyrannosaur dubbed the “reaper of death”&nbsphas been discovered in Canada,&nbspmarking the first new variant of the genus to be found in the country for 50 years.Thanatotheristes degrootorum – which gets its name from the Greek god of death Thanatos combined with theristes,&nbspone who reaps or harvests – the fossilised skull fragments and jaw bone of the the 79.5-milllion-year-old dinosaur were discovered by farmer and palaeontology enthusiast John De Groot as he hiked near Alberta.“The jawbone was an absolutely stunning find” he said. “We knew it was special because you could clearly see the fossilized teeth.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesNow research from the University of Calgary and the Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology has found Mr De Groot’s discovery is the oldest ever within the borders of Canada.“We are thrilled to announce the first new species of tyrannosaur to be discovered in Canada in 50 years,” said Dr François Therrien, curator of dinosaur palaeoecology at the Royal Tyrrell Museum.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Dinosaur skeletons captured in stunning detail Show all 16Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A ceratopsian, meaning 'horned face', the triceratops lived between 68-66 million years ago in the late Cretaceous period. Apple needs to fix those keyboards, he said. They are impossible to write on. They've gotten worse.It makes me want to go back to PCs. Because PC keyboards – the bounceback for your fingers is way better, he continued.Brie Larson catches Taika Waititi hiding his Oscar in unusual placeHe went on to explain that he has repetitive strain injury, which he said affects the tendon which goes down your forearm into the thumb. He also complained that users were forced to open their laptop and sit in uncomfortable positions.Waititi didn't specify which Apple keyboard or computer he so disliked. While he did make a passing reference to the iMac, his focus appears also to have been on the MacBook, which has accrued some unwanted fame for the reliability and feel of its keys in recent years.Late last year, Apple introduced a new keyboard with its new 16-inch MacBook Pro. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Scout leader says he is ‘fully recovered’ but still in quarantine, as neighbour warns against scapegoatingA man linked to 11 British coronavirus cases has been identified as businessman and scout leader Steve Walsh.Described as a so-called “super-spreader”, the 53-year-old picked up the virus during a business conference in&nbspSingapore, ahead of a ski holiday in the French Alps on 24 January.He returned to the UK four days later and was diagnosed on 6 February in Brighton. Five of the cases linked to Mr Walsh are in England, five are in France and one is in Majorca, Spain.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“I would like to thank the NHS for their help and care – whilst I have fully recovered, my thoughts are with others who have contracted coronavirus,” Mr Walsh said in a statement from quarantine in London’s St Thomas’ Hospital on Tuesday.“As soon as I knew I had been exposed to a confirmed case of coronavirus I contacted my GP, NHS 111 and Public Health England.Created with Sketch.China coronavirus: Cases soar of deadly new flu-like virus Show all 122Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Medical workers in protective suits move a patient at an isolated ward of a hospital in Caidian district following an outbreak of coronavirus in WuhanA worker in protective clothing, including face mask and gloves, carries a bucket as he works inside of The County Oak Medical Centre in Brighton, southern England, after it closed for urgent operational health and safety reasons, following reports a member of staff was infected with the strain of the novel coronavirusA woman repatriated from Wuhan carries a child as she walks upon her arrival at the Van Don airport in Vietnam's Quang Ninh provinceWorkers of the ecology and environment bureau collect samples from the sewage system of a hospital in Xinle, Hebei province5122 A man in protective clothing cleaning the County Oak Medical Centre GP practiceThe British government warned the outbreak of novel coronavirus was a serious and imminent threat and reported four new cases that brought the total recorded in the country to eight. scout leader feared “being made scapegoats for all this which would be totally unfair”. Ian Henshall told the site:&nbsp“He acted as quickly as he possibly could as soon as he got ill.”Elsewhere it is understood two prisoners at HMP Bullingdon in Oxfordshire are being tested for infection, with both reportedly in isolation while Public Health England conduct tests.The virus – now officially called Covid-19 – has so far killed more than 1,068 people in China according to the World Health Organisation (WHO), with more than 43,000 people in the country infected.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailAn additional 358&nbspinstances of the virus have been confirmed in 24 other countries outside of mainland China, with the only deaths confirmed in Hong Kong and the Philippines. Late on Tuesday Japan said there had been 39 more positive diagnoses aboard a cruise chip quarantined there.WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said any vaccine would be at least 18 months away.&nbsp“To be honest a virus is more powerful in creating political, social and economic upheaval than any terrorist attack,” he said. “It’s the worst enemy you can imagine.”As of Tuesday evening, a total of 1,358 people have been tested for coronavirus in the UK, of which 1,350 were confirmed negative and eight positive, the Department of Health said.Matt Hancock, the health secretary, told MPs in the Commons that new funding was being launched immediately “to support any urgent works the NHS needs for the coronavirus response, such as the creation of further isolation areas and other necessary facilities”.Of four Britons who tested positive for the virus on Monday, two were healthcare workers. Brighton’s County Oak medical centre was closed amid reports of workers wearing protective suits cleaning the surgery.On Tuesday evening it was revealed&nbspa healthcare worker at Worthing Hospital, near Hove, is&nbspamong the confirmed cases. Staff at the West Sussex hospital received a memo on Tuesday telling them an employee working in the A&ampE department had been diagnosed with the disease.Public Health England confirmed the newly announced cases were “closely linked” as efforts were made to trace other people who may have been exposed to the virus.The Singaporean authorities are said to be investigating the business meeting, attended by Mr Walsh with his company Servomex, alongside more than 90 other foreign nationals.&nbspServomex said “a limited number of its employees in different countries have been diagnosed with the coronavirus and are now being treated”.Officials hunt for patients of coronavirus-infected healthcare workersTrump cautioned for insisting ‘coronavirus will be gone by April’Should I pick up my family from the airport amid coronavirus outbreak?The Grand Hyatt Singapore, a five-star hotel with 677 guest rooms, said Singapore’s Ministry of Health informed it that three people who attended the conference experienced symptoms after returning to their home countries of Malaysia and South Korea and have now been diagnosed with the virus.The hotel said 94 foreigners stayed at the Grand Hyatt at the same time as the Servomex conference, including people from Wuhan, the Chinese city at the epicenter of the outbreak.The hotel said it is now deep-cleaning guest rooms, meeting spaces, restaurants, the fitness centre and other public areas.In Brighton, where several cases of coronavirus have been diagnosed, the County Oak Medical Centre closed its doors after reports one of the doctors working there had contracted the virus. A second branch of the surgery is also closed.Meanwhile in the US a patient in San Diego was accidentally discharged while carrying the virus after being given the all clear.In a statement UC San Diego Health confirmed one of four patients admitted after being evacuated from Wuhan had to be readmitted after further testing found evidence of the virus.The patient had been released into quarantine quarters at an airbase where they were being held for the duration of the virus’s incubation period.“The confirmed positive patient was returned to UC San Diego Health for observation and isolation until cleared by the CDC for release,” the hospital added.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet -
