story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Dismissal comes hours after Chancellor asked for a 'durable' system, in blow to Boris JohnsonThe EU's chief negotiator has immediately rejected&nbspa plea by Sajid Javid to protect the City's access to EU financial markets after Brexit.The Chancellor had called for a “reliable equivalence process” for financial services rules on which “a durable relationship” can be built with the EU.But just hours after the proposal was published Brussels' chief negotiator Michel Barnier&nbspdealt a blow to Boris Johnson's negotiating strategy.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesI would like to take this opportunity to make it clear to certain people in the United Kingdom bearing authority that they should not kid themselves about this - there will not be general, open-ended, ongoing equivalence in financial services, he said.Mr Barnier added that the EU would retain a free hand to take our own decisions and would simply not negotiate with the UK on this point.The Chancellor had said the Government wanted to conclude a full range of equivalence assessments by June 2020 - allowing the UK and EU to respect each other's rules.EU insists UK must keep regulations if it wants trade dealUK Brexit timetable not long enough for full trade deal, says Barnier‘Difficult to see’ how Brexit deal can be reached, EU’s Barnier saysBut he also said the UK would keep the freedom to erge and regulate in a different way from the rules set in Brussels.Each side will only grant equivalence if it believes the other's regulations are compatible, he wrote in the City AM newspaper.But compatible does not mean identical, and both the UK and the EU have at different times recognised the importance of focusing on regulatory outcomes.We will no longer be rule-takers, but we remain committed to the highest international standards of financial regulation and to shaping global rule-making.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Cities on the list include Arlington, Dallas, Denver, and Minneapolis&nbspChoosing where to live in the US&nbspcan be one of the hardest decisions one might make.&nbspCurbed, an American real estate and design blog, revealed its top 10 cities for people to settle down in that offer different&nbspopportunities&nbspcompared to the&nbspcountry's most populous areas.To create its list, the blog looked at criteria including walkability, park access, ersity, housing costs, and job opportunities in each city.&nbspThe criteria then combined to form the overall score of liveability for each city, helping Curbed compile&nbspits first-ever top 10 list for cities to move to in the&nbspUS.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesAs the home of the Pentagon, the city was previously seen&nbspas an extension of Washington DC&nbspfor people holding defence jobs, But Arlington&nbspis slowly creating an identity of its own, partly with the help of Amazon announcing its newest headquarters, HQ2, in the area.&nbspAmazon's first step to building its second HQ includes two 22-storey buildings, both set to start construction in the coming months and reach completion&nbspin 2023. The interest from the tech giant could&nbspdraw more tech industries&nbspin the coming years, bringing in&nbspjobs and people.&nbspAlthough the home prices continue to grow in Arlington,&nbspwith the median household costing $729,477, the ersity and potential job opportunities boosted the city onto the list.&nbspCreated with Sketch.The 30 most dangerous cities in the world Show all 30Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The most populous city in Idaho has seen a boom in the last decade from people moving away from areas in&nbspCalifornia in favour of a more affordable market —&nbspa point of frustration for longtime Boise residents.&nbspJob opportunities, specifically in the health and tech industries, aided in the boom of people moving to Boise. Cheaper housing, with the median home price $326,789, has also contributed to the interest.But while the new city boasts amenities that have people itching&nbspto move, it also needs to alter&nbspto the growing population as traffic increases and the downtown area becomes more packed.&nbspInterest in the city among the millennial generation has encouraged local developers&nbspto add a number of skyscrapers filled with apartments to house new residents.&nbspAnd the city skyline is not the only part changing.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Accessibility and its erse population helped place the southern&nbspcity on the top 10 places to move to in the coming years.&nbspDallas landed itself on the list for its ability to keep home and apartment prices relatively low, even in the downtown area.&nbspNot only are its low rental prices attracting people to move to the city, but it's also drawing in corporations interested in growing their businesses in the bustling metropolis.&nbspAs the most populous city on the list, there is concern it could become the&nbspNew York City of the south. But Dallas' ability to maintain low housing and rental costs solidifies it as an affordable alternative for city dwellers.&nbspThe last decade saw a significant population boom for the Mile High City. While some could credit the increase in residents to the state's decision to regulate marijuana, Denver also boasts a erse population and growing&nbspjob opportunities.&nbspHundreds search for missing 6-year-old girl in South CarolinaNew storm set to bring weekend power cuts and travel chaosThree migrants freeze to death after crossing US-Mexico borderWhat is the #broomchallenge and did it actually come from Nasa?Another perk? Denver offers those looking for an adventure the opportunity to leave the city easily to head up to nearby mountain towns.&nbspLike any growing city, Denver has to tackle an increase in traffic when travelling the metro area. But the city is determined to amend&nbspthe problem by building on its public rail service.&nbspPeople might view Madison as simply a college town, but the city offers more than students.&nbspThe small city flaunts&nbspa walkable downtown area that&nbspmakes travelling around a breeze. It also features&nbspjob opportunities, specifically in the tech industry, with the placement of healthcare IT giant Epic Systems nearby.&nbspTo further promote interest from non-college residents, the city is also making building developments a high priority. Prices remain affordable for newer residents with Madison's median home price $277,252Minneapolis experienced a real estate rush in recent years with the interest to redevelop the downtown area into a booming metropolis. Now the city is determined to focus on housing density and keeping homes affordable in the coming years.&nbspWhat helped place Minneapolis on the list is its accessibility for people to get around seamlessly, whether it be by car or on one of its many bike paths. The city also offers a strong&nbspeconomy with the help of giants like Target in town.&nbspHousing prices are anticipated to increase, but&nbspthe rates currently remain affordable with $277,252 as the median home price.&nbspThe least-known city on the list is Provo, Utah. Although the Mountain West city might get overlooked compared to Salt Lake City, it's seen a 20 per cent population growth between 2014 to 2019 due to interest from millennials.&nbspInterest in Provo is, in part, due to&nbspa range of job&nbspand housing options, attracting people away from the nearby Silicon Valley.Although ersity and the town's size is lacking, it still earned a place on the list as the city continues to develop into a larger metropolis.&nbspIn recent years, Raleigh's transformed from an industrial hub to providing jobs in the tech space for workers. These companies have then changed the warehouses scattered around the city into the ideal spaces for them to grow their businesses.&nbspBesides growing job opportunities, the city also reconstructed its downtown area to provide a space for more businesses.&nbspSt&nbspLouis was not a top contender for the list given its issues with ersity and declining population, while also&nbsphigh rankings in areas like walkability and transit. Curbed&nbsplisted&nbspthe city for its potential to grow into a new Midwestern hub, though, with companies like Microsoft and Square&nbspcoming in.&nbspThe city has to answer for its low appeal for a erse population, but there is potential for it to encourage startups to join the larger companies in developing the area.&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: bbc no longer loved broadcaster
story: If you are a lavishly overpaid BBC presenter or senior manager with your snout stuffed deep into the corporation’s publicly-funded trough, then three quid is nothing — around the price of a semi-skimmed latte made with almond milk from that delightful little café outside Broadcasting House.But coming when it did — immediately after the BBC’s wretchedly biased coverage of the moment we left the European Union — hiking the archaic telly tax felt grotesquely provocative.And I realised that the BBC’s big problem today is that it is unloved. The young folk born this century, like my -year-old daughter, do not watch it. The BBC means nothing to Generation YouTube.And the millions of us who grew up with the Beeb no longer recognise it as the benign Auntie that gave us Doctor Who, Top Of The Pops, Le On Earth, Fawlty Towers, The Likely Lads and David Dimbleby staying up all night at the General Election.That old beloved BBC — endlessly entertaining, scrupulously fair — is dead now. The BBC’s coverage of the night we left the European Union was nothing less than shameful.Here was a moment of truly historical signicance, the kind of national event that the BBC was born to cover. And it was dished up like a dull night at the Eurovision Song Contest.Down in Parliament Square, awash with Union Jacks and peaceful, happy patriots, BBC reporter Geeta Guru-Murthy blurted: “It’s a very white crowd mostly” — to the bewilderment of the many black and Asian people who were there to celebrate.But, of course, the BBC continues to peddle the filthy little lie that Brexit has its roots in the racism of the bigoted British people.Meanwhile, Sophie Raworth sat primly in a BBC studio made up to look like the EU flag. The studio never turned red, white and blue. There was no sense that the largest vote for anything in British history was being honoured. Why must we pay £billion a year for this one-sided garbage My colleague Ally Ross has pointed out that BBC “comedy” shows like Have I Got News For You, Frankie Boyle’s New World Order and The Mash Report have all been larded with anti-Brexit orthodoxy for years. Now the predictably loony Remainer-speak even seeps into the poison the BBC drips into our children.On the day we left the EU, the BBC released a CBBC Horrible Histories special mocking British stupidity.Queen Victoria was accused of callously sweetening her tea with sugar harvested by slaves — even though slavery was abolished four years before Victoria came to the throne.Historian Andrew Roberts described the mocking film as “a stream of bigoted hatred directed at this country”. They truly don’t get it in Broadcasting House. Millions of licence fee payers are deeply offended by the BBC’s relentlessly anti-British, anti-Brexit sentiment.It is why we fell out of love with the BBC. There is talk about decriminalising non-payment of the licence fee, or making payment optional. But the BBC no longer represents the entire nation. It peddles the prejudices of the disappointed elite who run it.The BBC does not speak for the British people. It doesn’t even seem to like us very much. So why should we pay anything at all for this crap AFTER being overlooked at the Oscars for her sensational performance in Hustlers, the half-time show at the Super Bowl felt like the revenge of Jenner Lopez.But Hustlers is my favourite film of the past  months. Lopez deserved an Oscar for her role.And whoever wins Best Actress at the Oscars tonight, I bet they can’t slide down a pole like her.MICHELLE OBAMA always said: “When they go low, we go high.”Meaning that when the Republican opponents of President Obama struck a low blow the Obamas had a strict policy of keeping their cool, their dignity and the moral high ground.The most senior Democratic politician in America just failed to take Michelle Obama’s advice. At his State of the Union address, President Trump petulantly refused to shake the hand of NancyPelosi, the Democratic Speaker of the House of Representatives. Pelosi should have shrugged off Trump’s rudeness and perhaps laughed in Donald’s orange face.Instead, clearly boiling with rage, Nancy ripped a copy of Trump’s speech to pieces. As the speech was full of optimistic stuff about making America a fairer, more prosperous place, the only person Pelosi humiliated was herself.The Democrats are starting to make Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party look like an effective opposition.THE classic James Bond films – Dr No, From Russia With Love, Goldfinger – were all less than two hours long.But in the modern fashion for over-long movies – The Irishman clocks in at three hours and  minutes – the next Bond film, No Time To Die, will be the longest ever at almost three hours.Let’s hope that means plenty of Ana de Armas, , as Bond girl Paloma. And not too much of Daniel Craig, , moaning about ’s dodgy knees.Teenage girls are messier than teenage boys. But teenage boys are, in my experience, more likely to leave takeaway pizza under the bed for six months for the mice to nibble.And when vermin move in, you really long for your little darling to move out.SUCKING up to the millionaire snowflakes in the audience, Prince William complained about the lack of ersity at the Baftas.I don’t believe it. This year a black actor, Micheal Ward, won the Rising Star Bafta for gang film Blue Story. Six years ago,  Years A Slave won Best Picture, competing with epic Hollywood fare like Gravity.If the film or performance is good enough, then the Baftas is colour blind.The real lack of ersity is among British actors. These days most of them went to Eton with Prince William. Now that’s what I call a lack of ersity.A SURVEY reveals that  per cent of Canadians are against paying the £million to-£million-a-year security bill for Harry and Meghan’s new le.Wherever they lay their hats, from Toronto to Tinsel Town, there is only one sucker who will ever pay for Harry and Meghan’s security. The poor old British taxpayer.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: jeremy corbyn picks nose and wipes it on his beard in the commons
story: The failed Labour leader finally picked a winner as he listened to his colleague Luke Pollard during a debate on the floods crisis.He then pulled his finger out and smeared it across his beard.Mr Corbyn is currently digging in deep as he remains in his role until a replacement is selected.The far-left leader’s successor will finally be announced on April .A Tory source said: After leading Labour to their worse defeat for  years, Corbyn nose hes now the bogeyman of Labour.A Labour source added: Jeremy clearly doesnt care any more. He nose his time is up.The gaffe comes less than  hours after the Sun revealed another Labour mishap, with fellow contender Emily Thornberry snapped putting her feet up on a commuter train.Sir Keir Starmer, Rebecca Long-Bailey, Lisa Nandy and Ms Thornberry are all vying for the top job.Mr Starmer is currently the favourite, with political betting aggregator BonusCodeBets having him at at  , Ms Long-Bailey at  , Ms Nandy on   and Ms Thornberry on  .

title: dan wootton another blow to the firm
story: THE Queen is used to her children orcing, but now the scourge has spread to her grandkids.And for a woman so set on the concept of marriage being a lelong commitment for the good of her church and her country, yet another messy and premature break-up will be galling.It’s also, let’s be blunt, the last thing the embattled monarchy needs right now after  months from hell.Of course, when all that is put to one side there is a very sad personal heartbreak here.Peter Phillips is the Queen’s beloved oldest grandson and an important figure for The Firm behind-the-scenes who has been close to William and Harry.Autumn’s decision to ask to separate will be devastating to him, given she was undoubtedly the love of his le and he has been open about being smitten from day one.Now the royals face the prospect of yet another one of their young families splitting their time between the UK and Canada, Autumn’s homeland where their children have dual citizenship.Even the suggestion that Autumn might be in some way inspired to follow the lead set by Harry and Meghan to spend more time in Canada will cause fury.It’s not an exaggeration to say that, at , the Queen will feel like she’s watching the disintegration of her once solid family unit.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sinn fein irish election britain
story: For anyone under  who does not realise the signicance, Sinn Fein was for decades the unashamed political wing of the Provisional IRA as it carried out a murderous spree in Northern Ireland and on mainland Britain.Under former president Gerry Adams, it always denied sharing a leadership, but few were convinced these two organisations were not effectively one and the same.As former IRA volunteer and Sinn Fein PR chief Danny Morrison memorably put it, the strategy for Irish Republicans was to seize power, “With a ballot paper in this hand and an Armalite in the other.”Sothey do manage to gain power — far from guaranteed with Ireland’s complex electoral system — what will it mean for Britain Sinn Fein continues to push for Irish unication. But providing it does so through democratic means only, that should not upset many people.After all, it is up to the people of Northern Ireland, through a referendum, to decide whether they want to remain part of the UK or to join Ireland.Sinn Fein can, however, be relied upon to be even more hostile than Leo Varadkar — up until now Ireland’s leader — towards Britain in trade negotiations with the EU.If the party can score some kind of victory by opposing UK proposals, it will do so, making it more likely we will have no trade deal by December .Sinn Fein has used Brexit to its advantage, trying to drive a wedge between Britain and those in Northern Ireland who traditionally want to stay part of the Union.By negotiating a deal which puts some kind of border down the Irish Sea, Boris Johnson’s government has helped Sinn Fein’s cause. Former Irish leader Bertie Aern claimed yesterday that a referendum on a united Ireland will now come before the end of the decade.“I think a border poll is inevitable,” he said. “I think it’s probably five years off at least but the Sinn Fein position is it should be held within five years.”It is easy to see a scenario in which Northern Ireland votes to leave the UK and join Ireland, followed by a Scottish vote for independence.I am not sure where that would leave Boris’s plans for a Belfast to Stranraer bridge, which of course would have been paid for mostly by English taxpayers.All this said, however, there is little to suggest that those who voted for Sinn Fein on Sunday were motivated by concerns over Brexit or by a desire for a united Ireland.Strip away its dubious past and Sinn Fein is now a party of the Corbynite Left — it wants far greater social programmes, all funded by the wealthy.This could have serious consequences in a country whose economic success is founded on low taxes, especially company taxes. Ireland’s corporation tax rate is just . per cent, compared with  per cent in the UK. That has helped it become a magnet for investment.In terms of GDP per head, Ireland was poorer than the UK  years ago, but now it is signicantly richer.But whatSinn Fein was able to do what Jeremy Corbyn promised to do and soak the rich We might no longer have a Celtic Tiger on our doorstep, but a Celtic Sloth. The likes of Amazon and Google, which have established big presences in Ireland for tax purposes, might want to sht operations to Britain instead.Leo Varadkar had hoped he would be rewarded at the ballot box for holding a tough line in Brexit negotiations, but Ireland’s housing crisis seems to have been a far stronger concern.Ireland, even more so than Britain, has suffered from property booms and busts over the past two decades.Many young people have been priced out of the housing market and are struggling to even rent. Sinn Fein did well because it promised a three-year rent freeze and , new homes.These pledges helped the party — which has dominated Republican politics in Northern Ireland — come out of the margins south of the border and break the duopoly of the two main partiesIt won . per cent of the vote, while Fianna Fail, a socially conservative party, won  per cent, and Fine Gael, the more economically and socially liberal party of Leo Varadkar, won just  per cent.If Ireland had Britain’s first-past-the-post system, it would have been a landslide — Sinn Fein topped the poll in  of the country’s  constituencies.But given Ireland’s system of multi-member constituencies, it is far from guaranteed that Sinn Fein will even be in government at all.Before the election, Fianna Fail and Fine Gael both said they would not go into government with Sinn Fein. They could go into coalition with each other.In fact, Fianna Fail was already propping up Fine Gael in a confidence and supply arrangement. But with Sinn Fein topping the poll, this might prove a more dficult position to hold.Sinn Fein says it is exploring trying to put together a government without either of the main parties.But despite winning the biggest share of the vote, Ireland’s political establishment may yet succeed in keeping it out of power — and away from messing up the Irish economy. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: house of lords insults democracy
story: The unelected chamber was already on thin ice before peers spent three years shamefully trying to overturn Brexit while pocketing £ a day tax-free.And you might think that, with their public standing now shredded, they would have the decency to freeze that rate. Especially with inflation at only . per cent. But no.They’ve voted themselves an inflation-busting . per cent instead — so they’ll now get £ just for showing up.A few Lords and Ladies have experience and ability, we admit. The rest shuffle in for the warmth and the cash.The truth is the House of Lords is an antiquated insult to our democracy, a dumping ground for political failures and discredited cronies, where almost no one is too odious . . . though it still draws the line at Bercow, obviously.A courageous Government with a big majority would take it on and reinvent it as a mainly elected second chamber — with a small handful of unelected peers chosen for specic expertise.How about it, Boris THE decision on whether to proceed with the HS high-speed rail project was bound to upset plenty of people whichever way it went.So perhaps it is no surprise that Boris Johnson has tried to appease both its supporters and opponents by pressing ahead with the bulk of the £billion project, while putting two of its northern spurs on pause.But the PM is shrewd enough to realise that the places losing out — Crewe to Manchester and the West Midlands to Leeds — are the very areas that he must keep on sidehis -seat majority is not to be a one-off.Boris’s alternative transport plans for them, with improved bus and cycle links just a start, must not let them down.Otherwise the snub could see Labour rebuild its “red wall” of voters as quickly as he demolished it.THE Cabinet reshuffle this week must be bold. It will define Boris’s premiership.There are obviously talented contenders for bigger jobs: among them Michael Gove, Rishi Sunak and Victoria Atkins.But this is not the moment for the PM to reward other time-servers whose turn has come. Boris must not overlook fresh faces from the  and  intakes and, while it is probably too early for December’s newcomers, why not,they have the talent This Government already has a place in history simply by forcing Brexit through on January .With dynamic, imaginative, bright and brave ministers it can be truly radical too. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus uk brit superspreader
story: Stephen Walsh, , unwittingly brought the deadly illness into the country last month after a business trip to Singapore and is feared to have infected dozens.His next-door neighbour, Ian Henshall, , said Mr Walsh is now “very concerned” that he will be held responsible for the outbreak.Mr Henshall told the Mirror: “I’ve spoken to his we Cathy directly and to Steve by email and they are absolutely terried of being made scapegoats for all this which would be totally unfair.“He acted as quickly as he possibly could as soon as he got ill. They are a lovely family. He is feeling fine now and Cathy is hoping he will be able to leave isolation and come home soon.“They are just obviously very concerned about being made scapegoats in all this.”It is feared Mr Walsh, a sales executive, may have spread the virus to dozens of people without suffering any symptoms himself.The dad of two has made his home town of Brighton the epi-centre of the UK coronavirus crisis.Do you know anyone infected with coronavirus  Contact joe.duggan@news or call   The seaside town and surrounding areas have seen health centres and care homes close, children staying away from school and a student at Sussex University being admitted to hospital.Elsewhere, prisoners at HMP Bullingdon, near Bicester, Oxfordshire, were confined to their cells after two inmates were suspected of carrying the virus — now officially known as Covid-.In Hove, East Sussex, members of Mr Walsh’s cub pack have been advised to “self-isolate” — with at least four families set to be tested for the virus after youngsters showed symptoms.A source said: “Parents are very worried.“At least four families believe their children have coronavirus and will be tested.“Apparently the children have started feeling unwell in the last couple of days, with flu-like symptoms. A message is being sent to everyone involved in Scouting in that part of Sussex.“Steve is a pillar of the local community and rubs shoulders with a lot of people in the area.“It’s obviously frightening because coronavirus could be very dangerous to young children.”Speaking from a quarantine unit at St Thomas’s Hospital in London, Mr Walsh, who beat the bug in five days, said: “I would like to thank the NHS for their help and care.“While I have fully recovered, my thoughts are with others who have contracted coronavirus.“As soon as I knew I had been exposed to a confirmed case of coronavirus I contacted my GP, NHS  and Public Health England.“I was advised to attend an isolated room at hospital, despite showing no symptoms, and subsequently self-isolated at home as instructed.“When the diagnosis was confirmed, I was sent to an isolation unit in hospital, where I remain, and, as a precaution, my family was also asked to isolate themselves.“I also thank friends, family and colleagues for their support during recent weeks and I ask the media to respect our privacy.”More than , people have died as the deadly virus tears through China.There have been more than , confirmed cases across the world.The total number of people infected in the UK has doubled in  hours to eight.Today, pupils at Cottesmore St Marys Catholic Primary School were told to remain at home after it was revealed that two people feared they caught the deadly disease from Mr Walsh and were in isolation.Students from Bevendean Primary School about three miles away were also warned to stay away after a staff member was advised to self-isolate after coming into close contact with a coronavirus patient.The County Oak Medical Centre in Brighton, East Sussex, was closed while staff in hazmat suits deep cleaned the surgery.Meanwhile, a second doctors surgery in the city — the Lions Dene surgery — linked to the Brighton coronavirus super-spreader, closed.Mr Walsh caught the virus at a conference at the Grand Hyatt hotel in Singapore organised by Servomex, a British gas analytics company.After the conference, he had a holiday in the French Alps with we Catherine and pals.Four of his friends — including Dr Catriona Greenwood and another GP — ed home on January  before testing positive at the weekend.Five more Brits who shared the ski chalet, including Dr Greenwood’s husband Bob Saynor and their nine-year-old son, are in hospital in France.Another expat also infected with the virus fell ill after ing home to Majorca, taking the number of confirmed cases linked to Mr Walsh to .It is thought any patients Dr Greenwood came into contact with will be approached for testing.She works as a locum at the practice which has since been shut for decontamination as officials scramble to trace patients to be tested. On Monday the government announced cops can now legally detain high-risk patients after one threatened to storm out of Arrowe Park Hospital on The Wirral, Merseyside.A security guard said: “One patient got drunk and threatened to leave.”And they will also be allowed to hunt and capture peoplethey may be infected. The new law was rushed through yesterday.The NHS have two quarantine sites, the other is in Milton Keynes, Bucks.The Health department yesterday declared the coronavirus outbreak a serious threat to the public.So far, a total of , people have been tested in Britain, with , testing negative.CORONAVIRUS may be killing up to one in five people at the centre of the outbreak who catch it, a study suggests.The “case fatality ratio”for people in Hubei Province is  per cent.Outside China it is between . and . per cent, researchers from Imperial College London found.Variations in diagnosis and care across countries are likely to account for the dferent outcomes. The figures could also change as health chiefs collect better data on cases, deaths and recovery.Professor Neil Ferguson said the estimates did not “reflect underlying dferences in disease severity between countries.“All CFR estimates should be viewed cautiously as the sensitivity of surveillance of both deaths and cases in mainland China is unclear,” he said.There are now more than , confirmed cases of the virus worldwide, with over  deaths.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: five schools on coronavirus infection alert
story: Panicked parents pulled kids out of Cottesmore St Marys Catholic and Bevendean Primary School in Brighton over fears the deadly disease is spreading.Meanwhile one of the seaside city’s largest ‘self-isolate’ for  days by Public Heath England, the Daily Mail reports.Brighton has become the epi-centre of the virus after a cub Scout leader dubbed the Coronavirus “super-spreader” unwittingly to collect their children.“The kids can have the rest of the week off and then it’s half term next week.“The school said they’ve already done a deep clean and they’ll be doing another one every parent would do and came straight down to pick my children up.“The school has said it is a safe environment but I just wanted to be sure and picked them up straight away.”Another distressed mum recalled how she picked up her five-year-old daughter instantly after receiving the email.Not willing to take any risks, she added that her child will go back to school once they give her the all-clear.She said: “I will be keeping my daughter at home until I receive  per cent confirmation it’s safe to do so.“The school has taken the right precautions and there are hand sanitisers all around the building.“But I still had to do the right thing and pick her up.”Sarah Lewis, , whose six-year-old daughter goes to Cottesmore, told Sun Online: “Apparently a lot of kids were taken out [by parents]. They are worried.“They had a full assembly with hand washing and they all got a bottle of sanitiser and they were told to keep their hands washed.“I’m aware of the risks – would it be mad to send her, would it be mad not to  I’ve still got to go to work.”Natalie Brown, whose children also go to the school, said she was shocked to learn the news.She told BBC Radio : Parents with children with heart conditions and asthma are obviously concerned as their children would be deemed as high risk.But Ms Brown also criticised the lack of information about coronavirus and called for better communication.She added: We received a letter today telling us that two people are in self-isolation for  days after coming into contact with the coronavirus.Last week, the children were all given anti-bacterial hand gel as a precaution, leading to questions about what was known then and what has since been communicated to us.Concerned parents at Bevendean Primary School also told The Argus their children had been given the option to stay home.A mother with a six-year old son at the school said: “I’m still shaking.I was going to take my child to school, but then I got the email at . this morning — I’m just glad I checked.“The pupils have been given the choice whether to go in or not ­– it’s up to parents, andthey take the time off it goes down as an authorised absence.Dr Catriona Greenwood is thought to be one of the two medics infected — and may have passed the bug on to patients.It comes after a second doctors surgery in the city — the Warmdene surgery — linked to the Brighton coronavirus super-spreader, closed.Dr Greenwood works as a locum at the practise which has since been shut for decontamination as officials scramble to trace patients to be tested.The surgery is part of the same practise as the County Oak Medical Centre, which was closed while staff in hazmat suits deep cleaned the surgery yesterday afternoon. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: terrifying moment school bus flips over sending kids flying before ultra calm driver saves them from the wreckage
story: The bus collided at an intersection in Ohio with a Ford Mustang that police said failed to stop at a red light and then flipped over.Footage released by the Ohio State Highway Patrol shows the  students thrown onto the ceiling of the bus after it hit the car at the intersection of State Route  and State Route .In the video, some of the kids can he heard crying and screaming after being hurled around the bus, which ends up on its side.The -year-old driver Danny Hupp can he heard calmly telling kids to escape through windows and the emergency exit.Hupp and eight of the students needed hospital treatment for non-le threatening injuries.Student Ayden Lutz told ABC: We were pretty lucky, honestly. The whole front end of the bus was basically in pieces.I just remember the bus sliding to the left and it flipped me, hitting the ceiling.”Principal Lisa Householder said “she couldnt be more proud” of the students who she said were “heroic”.She said students were helping each other and took handle of the situation to do a phenomenal” job of evacuating the bus.Northern Local School District superintendant Tom Perkins said the crash reiterates the importance of safety drills.I will see that bus in my dreams for years to come. title: owner slices dogs tongue hammer
story: The -year-old, who has not been named, battered Staffordshire Terrier Dwayne with the tool then failed to take him to the vets in New South Wales.The RSPCA released pics of the dogs injuries to raise awareness of the horric cruelty it suffered.Shocking footage of the scene - too graphic to be released - shows a hammer in the man’s right hand as he chases Dwayne around the garden.He swings the hammer and hits the poochs back legs of the dog before cornering the helpless creature and pummelling more blows down it.The dog appears to be held and hit with the hammer a further  times.Witnesses claim he yelled that the dog had destroyed his synthetic grass before taking it inside.RSPCA New South Wales was called and sent inspectors round with police officers the same day.They found bloodstains on the backyard and the two dogs locked inside the laundry room.The officials called a locksmith so they could free the animals.Dwayne was seized and immediately transported to RSPCA NSW Sydney Shelter for veterinary treatment.RSPCA Inspectors ed to the property on  November  and cautioned the defendant, who initially denied any wrongdoing.After being told about the video footage, he admitted that he had hit the dog with the hammer.The man handed the dog over to authorities.A vet found that Dwayne had injuries consisted with blunt force trauma, lacerations to the tongue, facial bruising and a fracture tooth.During his sentencing at Mt Druitt Local Court in NSW, Australia, Magistrate Corry told him: You left that dog in continuing pain as a result of not minor injuries, requiring medical treatment.“Put yourself in the dog’s positionyou were the subject of an assault. They feel pain. You should reflect on that.The man was placed on an aggregate four-month intensive corrections order.He must complete  hours of community service work and exhibit good behaviour, RSCPA NSW reported.RSPCA NSW Chief Inspector Scott Meyers said: “There is nothing your pet can do which justies treating them in this manner.Pets look to their owners for the basics, food water shelter, but also love and affection.This is a very serious example of offending and is further compounded by allowing this dog to continue to suffer as a result of his own actions. title: prince harry meghan markle sale cost monarchy

story: The man in his s had gone for a walk when he was struck by the branches in Woolton, Liverpool, this morning.Emergency services and heartbroken witnesses raced to the woods and found the loyal title: hs2 high speed rail project
story: NewsHS: Where will high speed rail project go and will it make my journeys faster Boris Johnson has finally given the costly rail project the green light - but whose idea was it, and when will it be finished  Heres everything you need to knowShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  FEB News " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBoris Johnson has finally given the green light to the controversial HS project despite soaring costs and environmental concerns. He faced down Tory opposition to the rail scheme - including in his own Cabinet - saying the Government has “got to have guts” to deliver. The Prime Minister admitted that costs have “exploded” from the original £bn bill to as high as £bn. He blamed the eye-watering sums - which some MPs want to be spent on local transport instead - on “poor management” by the firm responsible. The Government plans to appoint a minister whose full-time job it would be to manage the project.But Labour accused ministers of being unable to properly manage big infrastructure projects or “keeping a lid” on the costs.And it warned that Mr Johnson had promised much to the people of the Midlands and North during the election - but they would end up “sorely disappointed” when they saw how it worked out.Outgoing leader Jeremy Corbyn claimed the PM was fond of announcing “big shiny projects” which didn’t amount to much. Mr Johnson’s own record on such projects includes a Garden Bridge and Thames Estuary Airport which flopped when he was London Mayor. The first stage of High Speed , which will kick off next month, will go from London to Crewe, reducing journey times considerably.  Delivery of the Northern stages to Manchester and Leeds will be reviewed to try to cut costs and speed up the timetable. Mr Johnson wants to integrate the final stages with existing - and future - rail links across the North.   This includes Northern Powerhouse Rail which would stretch from Liverpool to Hull, adding £bn to the total bill.  The PM told the Commons: “We face a historic choice, we can try to get by with existing routes from North to South or we can have the guts to take a decision, no matter how dficult and controversial.” But Tory MP Andrew Bridgen, whose constituency will be cut in two by the HS, said HS was “unloved, unwanted and has been grossly mismanaged”. And Greenpeace’s John Sauven said Mr Johnson’s decision would give him the “dubious honour” of being this century’s largest destroyer of ancient woodlands. Where will HS go  The high-speed railway line will go from London to Birmingham and then a Y-shaped extension in two phases - the first from the West Midlands to Crewe followed by the second from Crewe to Manchester, and Birmingham to Leeds. It will carry m-long trains with as many as , seats each, running at mph and  times an hour in each direction. Building work will begin on the route to Birmingham next month. Whose idea was it Gordon Brown’s Labour government backed the high-speed line in  to address capacity issues on the West Coast mainline. They suggested it should eventually extend to Scotland. But the UK’s first high-speed link came with the opening of the -mile line between London and the Channel Tunnel. HS was supported by the coalition and Theresa May’s government, and now by Boris Johnson.Why do we need it  Britain’s crumbling rail network dates back to the Victorian era and trains are limited to speeds no greater than mph. Demand for both passenger and rail freight has increased dramatically over the last two decades but the capacity of the network has not. With HS more people will be able to use the train and journey times will fall - boosting the economy of the North and Midlands. How much will it cost   The official price tag for HS was announced in the  Budget and came in at just under £bn. The Government now estimates the cost has increased to between £bn and £bn for the whole route. The Oakervee review into the project recommended ministers should proceed - but his deputy didn’t agree and put the final bill as high as £bn. Adding HS right across the Pennines would add at least £bn to the bill.  What went wrong  The PM has blamed poor management by HS Ltd, the firm set up to run the project. The cost has spiralled in part because of unrealistic land and property valuations for the areas it cuts through and the expense of tunnels underneath the Chilterns and central London. Whitehall spending watchdog the National Audit Office blamed the complexity of the project and said risks were under-estimated. Is it worth the money  Successive prime ministers - now including one-time sceptic Boris Johnson - think it will deliver a huge boost to the economy. Doug Oakervee, who led the review into the project, claimed it would give aof £ to £. for every £ spent over  years. But his deputy Lord Berkeley thought it would deliver aof just p. Ministers now think the figure is around £. for each pound invested. How long will the project take to build  Stage one from London to the West Midlands was due to open at the end of . But Transport Secretary Grant Shapps admitted last year it could now be - before the first trains run, which has been pushed back to . The second phase to Manchester and Leeds was due to open in -, but that has now been delayed to -. The PM has said he wants the North to feel the benefits well before then. What dference will it make to my journey The DfT claims it will cut journey times from London to Birmingham from one hour  minutes to just  minutes from London to Birmingham.Journeys from London to Manchester will go down from two hours seven minutes to one hour seven minutes, while going from the Midlands to Leeds will take just  minutes. The PM claims journeys from Glasgow to London will be  minutes quicker.

title: number 10 steps up revenge
story: NewsNumber  steps up revenge on judges plan after humiliating deportation blowDominic Cummings said the ruling showed an "examination" of judicial review was needed - but others warned Boris Johnsons team is gearing up for a bitter revenge attack on judges after the Brexit battles of last yearShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBoris Johnson is set to step up his plan to apostake revengeapos on judges after suffering another humiliating defeat at the hands of the courts. It comes after the Court of Appeal ruled against the government, preventing them from deporting  foreign offenders scheduled to be on a deportation flight this morning. The Prime Minister has already announced a “constitution, democracy and rights commission” tasked with ensuring judicial reviews are not “abused to conduct politics by another means or to create needless delays.”Mr Johnson was left fuming after judges unanimously ruled his plan to shut down parliament and ram his Brexit plan through was unlawful.Judicial reviewis the process where members of the public can take the government to court to rule on whether their actions are lawful. It’s a crucial power of the court system, and exists to make sure governments - however strong their hold on power - have to operate within the law. The Conservative manesto promised to examine the JR process to ensure it is not abused for political reasons. Downing Street said it bitterly regretted the Court of Appeal decision and Government sources said the row over the deportation flight showed why an examination of JR was needed.  A dozen separate applications for JR were filed in recent days in relation to the deportation flight, sources said. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said: The legal process for removing these offenders, which has included repeated appeals and judicial reviews, has already cost the British public tens of thousands of pounds. Dominic Cummings, one of the Prime Ministeraposs closest aides, said there must be urgent action on the farce that judicial review has become following the Court of Appeal decision, ITV News reported. The Tories also seized on Labouraposs criticism of the flight and claimed it showed they have not learned the lesson of the  electoral drubbing. A senior Government source said: The Westminster bubbleaposs view in trying to halt this flight with repeated JRs makes the case perfectly to the public about why such a review is needed and why certain parts of Westminster still havenapost learned the lesson from the  election. Labour has challenged the Government in Parliament about allowing the flight to take off before the findings of the review into the Windrush scandal have been published.Amanda Pinto QC, chair of the Bar Council, said: Judicial review is a hugely important tool in a democratic society by which decisions of public authorities, including government, are subject to legal scrutiny. Far from being a mark of dys, judicial review is an appropriate check on decision-making, of which a nation should be proud.  She added: We have not yet seen details of what a aposreviewapos of the judicial review process might look like, but anything that seeks to limit the ability of ordinary citizens to challenge decisions of those with power is a red flag. Caroline Goodwin QC, of the Criminal Bar Association, said: Judicial review is a process to keep a check on authorities acting beyond the legal remit that may have been granted to them by the law, thus playing a part to ensure the law applies equally to everyone this is what the rule of law means.Shadow attorney general Baroness Chakrabarti said: There is no democracy without the rule of law. These attacks on journalists and judges are chronic symptoms of an entitled Tory Government that is desperate to avoid scrutiny, and is out of control. When the review was first mooted last month, Baroness Chakrabarti told the Mirror it was revenge for losing -nil in the Supreme Court. She added: It’s like losing -nil in the cup final and coming with a baseball bat for the referee.” Acting Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey said: These Tory attacks on our courts, judicial review and the Human Rights Act are all designed to weaken ordinary people and enable ministers to act with impunity. They are the actions of despots, not democrats.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe spread of coronavirus will get worse before it gets better, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said today. As of Tuesday afternoon, a total of , people have been tested for coronavirus, of which , were confirmed negative and eight positive. But announcing greater powers and funding to help tackle the spread of the disease, Mr Hancock said there was still a struggle to come. In a Commons statement, he told MPs: Dealing with this disease is a marathon, not a sprint. The situation will get worse before it gets better. Mr Hancock said the risk to the public remains moderate and the eight patients with confirmed cases of coronavirus in the UK are receiving expert care. Tracing those who have been in contact with the first four cases is now complete and tracing those who have been in contact with the remaining four cases is ongoing, he told MPs. Mr Hancock also announced new capital funding for the NHSthey need to create further isolation areas and other necessary facilities. He said: Today I can announce to the House the immediate launch of a capital facility to support any urgent works the NHS needs for the coronavirus response such as the creation of further isolation areas and other necessary facilities. Responding, shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth said: I understand why the Secretary of State has invoked the regulations that heaposs entitled to do under the Public Health Act. He has our support. Quarantine arrangements must be seen to be necessary, proportionate and in accordance with law.  And enforcement of those arrangements including with powers of restraint where necessary must be fully transparent and the rights and freedoms of the quarantined evacuees must be fully understood, so as to ensure they are treated with dignity and respect. So we agree that a legislative framework for this is far preferable to ad hoc contracts that were the original basis for the quarantine and in order to maintain public confidence in these arrangements that framework must be understood and scrutinised by Parliament.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA dad-of-two identied as Britain’s coronavirus super-spreader has told how he fears being made a “national scapegoat”. Scout leader Steve Walsh, , today told of his concern for the  Brits he has infected from his hospital bed in a London isolation unit. Health authorities are trying to trace hundreds of people he and other Brits he infected came in to contact with since theirto the UK. The group of friends who have tested positive include two GPs and the outbreak has seen two doctors surgeries and a care home closed in the Brighton area. Two teachers at sales executive Mr Walsh’s daughter’s school were today ordered to “self isolate”. He is in quarantine at London’s St Thomas’ Hospital after picking up the disease at a Singapore gas conference at the end of last month. He then come home to Hove in East Sussex via a skiing holiday. Friends who he stayed with in a chalet in the French Alps have also tested positive and half of the groups had ed to the UK.  Mr Walsh said in a statement: “I would like to thank the NHS for their help and care. “Whilst I have fully recovered, my thoughts are with others who have contracted coronavirus. “As soon as I knew I had been exposed to a confirmed case of coronavirus I contacted my GP, NHS  and Public Health England. “I was advised to attend an isolated room at hospital, despite showing no symptoms, and subsequently self-isolated at home as instructed. “When the diagnosis was confirmed I was sent to an isolation unit in hospital, where I remain, and, as a precaution, my family was also asked to isolate themselves. “I also thank friends, family and colleagues for their support during recent weeks and I ask the media to respect our privacy.” Mr Walsh is assistant cub scout leader at the rd Hove St Leonards Scout Group where the children know him as Shere Khan. Ian Henshall, a -year-old author, has lived next door to Steve Walsh for  years.  He said: “I’ve spoken to his we Cathy directly and to Steve by email and they are absolutely terried of being made scapegoats for all this which would be totally unfair. “He acted as quickly as he possibly could as soon as he got ill. They are a lovely family. He is feeling fine now and Cathy is hoping he will be able to leave isolation and come home soon. “They are just obviously very concerned about being made scapegoats in all this.” Two teachers at the primary school where one of Mr Walsh’s two children normally attends were today in “self-isolation”. Authorities at Cottesmore St. Mary Catholic Primary in Hove have now told parents they are allowed to keep their children at homethey are at all concerned. It is understood Mr Walsh’s young daughter is usually a pupil in Year Six at the school. And head teacher Rachel Breen has now written to parents telling them of the two “staff isolations” which were being carried out to “reduce the risk of the virus spreading”. Mrs Breen explained: “We have been informed that two people, from our school, have been advised by Public Health England to self-isolate for  days after coming into contact with a Coronavirus case.  “I appreciate it may be concerning that people have been told to ‘self-isolate’. However, this is a purely precautionary measure to help reduce the risk of the virus spreading. “As part of self-isolation neither person is in school.” Parents were told they could keep their children off schoolthey wish. Steve lives with his we Catherine and contracted the virus during a conference at the Grand Hyatt hotel in Singapore organised by Servomex, a British gas analytics company he works for, more than two weeks ago. He then travelled to Les Contamines-Montjoie, near Megeve, for a ski break to stay with friends Bob Saynor and his we Dr Catriona Saynor, who own the chalet where  people were exposed to the virus. They are both believed to have coronavirus and so has their nine-year-old son. Mr Walsh flew from Geneva to London on an easyJet plane with -plus passengers and crew before going to his local pub, The Brigadier in Hove. He also attended a yoga class at a local community centre. He went on to call NHS  with concerns about coronavirus and was advised to go to Royal Sussex County Hospital Brighton, for testing. Separately two prisoners at Bullingdon Prison in Oxfordshire were being tested for the bug and awaiting results. They were reportedly tested after a man who transferred from a jail in Thailand collapsed in his cell tonight. All prisoners on C-wing were being kept under lockdown in their cells last night. The Saynors live in France for most of the year and school pupils and teachers who came in close contact with the nine-year-old boy have been told to self-isolate for two weeks.  Dr Saynor and another male GP were among the recent four Brits to test positive in the UK, bringing the total to eight. Before being isolated it is feared they came in to contact with patients and staff at two branches of the County Oak Medical Centre as well as Patcham Nursing Home. All have been closed and are undergoing decontamination. One of the GPs’ patients, a -year-old mother-of-four from Brighton, said: “I was here on the February rd and the th and they will not tell me the risk even though I am immunosuppressed with lupus. “Nobody knows anything. It’s a farce. Everybody is worried about it. No-one can protect themselves and we can’t protect the public. I am going to ring  and [Public] Health England until I get some answers.” GP surgeries across Brighton are questioning patients on their possible exposure to an infected person before they are being granted an appointment. Paul Cosford, emeritus medical director of Public Health England , said: “I should say that the people who are of concern are those who have had very close contact with somebody with coronavirus - face-to-face contact or within a two-metre range for  minutes or more.”  “A small number of them will be patients who these healthcare workers have been involved with treating but it is actually a relatively small number.” The eight cases in the UK include Mr Walsh, the five friends he infected, and two Chinese visitors who had been staying in York. Five more Brits staying at the French chalet have tested positive. Four are under quarantine in France while one man had ed to his home in Majorca. Public health officials have been accused of ‘losing control’ and keeping ‘secrets’ from the public. Prof Paul Hunter, from the University of East Anglia, said: “Patient confidentiality is important but we may now be at the point where the public’s need to know more information is greater. “It would be helpful to know[Mr Walsh] got a taxi straight home or got a bus and stopped off at the supermarket. Letting the public know this timeline will reassure many that they are not at risk.” It comes as the head of the World Health Organisation announced a name for the new coronavirus - Covid-.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCampaigning mum Marie McCourt was praised for her “bravery and determination” in the House of Commons as ‘Helen’s Law’ moved one step closer to reality. Marie, , attended Parliament with husband John Sandwell, , to hear the second reading of the bill passed unanimously. For over an hour MPs from all parties gave emotive speeches in support of the law - with one describing it as being of “particular public interest and importance”. Justice Minister Chris Philp added: “We are striking a blow today for the rights of victims, a blow for the rights of their families who deserve to be able to move on with their lives following crimes of the most appalling kind.” Marie’s MP Conor McGinn also publicly thanked the Mirror for supporting the campaign for many years. Justice Secretary Robert Buckland said: “This is a short bill, it consists of just three clauses but its importance cannot be underestimated. “It responds directly to real-le issues that we know have caused, and continue to cause, immense distress to the families of victims of serious crimes. “Despite its full and proper title this is a bill that we have all come to know as ‘Helen’s Law’. “...Helen’s mother Marie McCourt has long campaigned for this change in the law. “I want to take this opportunity, and I’m sure the whole house will want to join me, to pay tribute to her bravery, her determination and her tenacity.” Helen McCourt, , was murdered by pub landlord Ian Simms as she walked home from work in . Her body has never been found despite three decades of searches by her devoted mum and family.  Many of the MPs who spoke during todayaposs session have constituents who have suffered similar heartbreak. Stephen Metcalfe MP referenced Linda Jones, whose -year-old daughter Danielle was murdered by her uncle in . The schoolgirl’s body has never been found but her killer Stuart Campbell is up for parole next year. MP Metcalfe said: “This is not some technical law change, Madam Deputy Speaker, this is about real people, real victims, real families and real hurt and anguish.  “This is about Helen McCourt and her family, about my constituent Linda Jones and her family and her murdered daughter Danielle Jones. “And it’s about all the families who have been denied the opportunity to put to rest a loved one killed or murdered in the most distressing way.” Justice Minister Philp challenged Campbell directly saying: “The message that Stuart Campbell and other people like him should hear loud and clear, on this day, from this house, is that their failure to disclose is unacceptable.  “It is abhorrent and they should make that disclosure right away.” Helen’s Law, launched by the Mirror in , means parole judges will be legally obliged to consider “non-disclosure” by prisoners when considering release requests. There was anger in the House that the legislation may have come too late for Marie, who received the news last week that killer Simms, now , had been released. But she has pledged to keep fighting against his freedom and is still awaiting a Judicial Review of the decision to grant him parole. MP McGinn, of Saint Helens North, said: “It is bittersweet because as many in the House will know, just last week Helen McCourt’s murderer was released from prison.  “...The parole board in my view made an appalling decision.” The PrisonersBill contains a second section relating to non-disclosure by sex offenders. Vanessa George recently walked free from a  year prison sentence after abusing children at the nursery where she worked. Parents of the youngsters who attended the nursery still have no idea whether their kids were among her victims.

title: mum who doesnt send kids
story: NewsMum who doesnt send her kids to school swears by letting them make own decisionsNic Bescoby, from Rochdale, has scrapped traditional parenting and lets her three children do what they want, when they want - insisting it has made for a happier homeShareCommentsByHarriet Whitehead:,  FEB NewsNic with her three kids George, Ellie and Aimee " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A mum whose kids donapost go to school swears by aposunschoolingapos her kids and letting them make their own decisions.Nic Bescoby has scrapped traditional parenting and lets her three children do what they want, when they want. Having read up on ‘gentle’ parenting, she follows the method based on mutual respect and willingness, rather than demands and rules. Her kids decide for themselves what and when to eat and when to sleep - usually falling asleep between pm and am. And Nic insists her technique has tackled meltdowns and made for a happier home. It all began when Nic discovered a rigid routine did not work well with her aposspiritedapos eldest George, eight. But now Nic, , swears by ‘unschooling’– where children learn only what they want to, rather than following a set curriculum. The blogger from Rochdale, who studied childcare at college, lets her kids choose how to structure their days. And Nic, who is also mum to Ellie, seven, and Aimee, six, insists her brood are creative, kind and love learning as a result of their bohemian upbringing. She explained: “There is no schoolwork - it’s mostly discussion. Children are naturally curious. They will ask questions, and we will offer them an answer, or research it together using the internet or books. “I learn myself alongside them. For example, Aimee will ask me how something works, like the veins in her wrist, and we talk about that. “They love to listen to me read classic literature, so we will read Shakespeare and Dickens together. At the moment, we’re reading Percy Jackson, which is teaching us about Greek mythology. “I respect them as people and as equals. I guide them and teach them - but we are still equals.” Nic, who co-parents her children with their father - her ex-husband, factory worker Kyle Dex,  - had a conventional upbringing herself, but found that attending a mainstream school took the joy out of learning. Her early experiences with education were also marred by the fact that, growing up, she was bullied at school. She added: “I had a fairly average upbringing. My mum was neither strict nor lenient, and I was educated at school. I found it killed any love of learning for me, because everything was forced.”  Then, having learned about dferent styles of parenting whilst studying childcare, she decided to adopt an ‘authoritarian’ approach after George was born in April . “I was taught a very linear punishment and reward type system, which I was using at first,” she said. “But I soon realised that wasn’t going to work with George. “He was a very spirited child and would have meltdowns. The punishment and reward system wasn’t making either of us happy.” So, when George was around two and in nursery, Nic decided to change tack, having read up on ‘gentle’ parenting - a method based on mutual respect and willingness, rather than demands and rules, where a parent will offer guidance, but ultimately, children make their own decisions.  She recalled: “I noticed a dference immediately. I told George, ‘You choose what you want to do,’ and from then on, we weren’t struggling anymore. Before, he’d have several meltdowns a day. He was losing it over everything we tried to control and getting frustrated with us telling him what to do - but we changed our methods and they reduced to just a couple a week.” George remained in nursery for just eight weeks, then Nic and Kyle agreed to remove him. She added: “We weren’t happy with him being there. It felt wrong to have him away from the family.” Since then, George has not set foot in a mainstream school – and neither have his siblings. Nic added: We did try home-schooling where we focused on set topics, but this didnapost really work, because we were missing out on things we wanted to learn. Then, we learned about unschooling online in parenting and home education groups. Describing her family as being at the aposextreme endapos of unschooling, Nic said that the first drastic change made was to their daily routine - scrapping mealtimes and bedtimes.  “We allow the children to come to us when they are hungry,” she explained. “I will leave snacks out for them to pick at, like breadsticks, bits of fruit and veg and sweets and chocolatethey wish, orthey want a meal, we will decide together what they are going to have, so it gives them control. “We have taught them about food, what their bodies need and the dferent nutrients and will cook together. “They usually go to sleep between pm and am. They have never gone to sleep on their own. I will sit with them and we will sing or listen to a podcast. “I remember as a kid feeling sad waiting to fall asleep, or having a nightmare, and I never want them to feel like that. I want it to be this lovely, cosy experience for them. “They fall into a natural rhythm and will sleep and wake when they want to. I’ll only set an alarmwe have to be somewhere.”  With no set bedtime either, the family spend the evening watching movies, reading books, doing arts and crafts, or learning. Curiosity, rather than curriculums, dictate exactly what the children learn each day, and a lot of their education is very hands-on. Nic continued: “As long as they are not breaching health and safety, they can do what they like. We love getting out in nature and spend a lot of time camping. We learn about foraging and dferent animals. “George became interested in bushcraft and started making bowls from branches. He also likes trains and trams, so we went on a tour to find out how they – and electricity – work. “He does a lot of video gaming, like Minecraft, so has learned how to type, read and write notes to his friends through that. “We have never sat down and done a lesson on reading and writing. They are just picking it up. The girls’ vocabulary is unbelievable. “I can’t imagine them being sat in a classroom. When I compare what they would have to do at school with what they do today, I realise it would never work for them.” When it comes to discipline, Nic believes that by having healthy discussions, rather than punishing her children, she will guide them towards making their own decisions. If any family members are ever feeling frustrated, they will have apostable timeapos, where everyone gathers to discuss their issues.  She said: “The conventional thinking is that you have to tell children what to do otherwise they won’t do it, but from my point of view, when you give them the information, they are good at processing that information and meeting their own needs. “I’m not perfect and will lose my temper but we do not do punishment, we try to do everything through discussion.” Hoping that she is raising three independent children who know their own minds, Nic also allows the children free reign over their appearance, letting them dye their hair or wear make-upthey want to. Ellie is creative and loves cosmetics and colouring her hair bright green, while Aimee previously insisted on wearing odd shoes for a year-and-a-half. “They like to decorate their clothes with paint,” Nic said. “If they want to wear pyjamas in the daytime, they are allowed to. We have a single box of clothes and they can choose from there.“As long as it’s safe, the clothes are clean and weather appropriate then I don’t mind. It’s allowing them to be creative.Although she cannot see them wanting to, Nic says she would enrol the children into a mainstream schoolthey expressed a wish to go. “You can’t say have autonomy in one area and not another - although I can’t see why they would choose formal education over the freedoms they have now,” she said. She says people do question her methods, but they are mostly just curious, or surprised that unschooling is legal. Under current UK law, parents are permitted to teach their children at home, either full or part-time, and do not have to follow the national curriculum. However, they must ensure their children are in full-time learning from the age of five, and councils can make informal inquiries to check that a suitable education is being given. On one occasion, Nic was told by a stranger that her children aposwill never get on in leapos unless she puts them into a mainstream school – but she disagrees, and has high aspirations for George, Ellie and Aimee.

She then watched the resulting blaze spread from a neighbouring property. Appearing at Sheffield Crown Court on Friday , Mallett was sentenced to nine years behind bars having already admitted to starting the blaze at an earlier hearing. The court heard how the offence was carried out in Maltby near Rotherham, South Yorkshire, in the early hours of December , . At the time, the homeowner had a restraining order against Mallett after being subjected to an earlier assault and criminal damage. Emergency services rushed to the scene after a passing off-duty police officer saw the house was on fire. Having fled the property Mallet watched the fire from a nearby address as firefighters and neighbours rushed to help. Fortunately, the victim was able to escape unscathed and Mallett was arrested shortly afterwards before being charged with arson with intent to endanger le. The defendant has previously been convicted for committing arson at the properties of men she has slept with men who were up to  years her senior. Speaking after the sentencing, Detective Constable Paul McIntyre, of Rotherham CID said: “It’s important to recognise the background to this incident, where Mallett had essentially taken advantage of a very vulnerable man and had used him for money, alcohol and somewhere to stay. title: bow united no longer jealous of other clubs
story: Academies weren’t a part of football when Dave Bowman was making his way in the game.However, the Dundee United legend feels they are becoming increasingly important after the club’s youth set-up recently achieved Elite status.Former United midfielder Bow, player transition coach at the club’s academy, is delighted the Tangerines have reached that landmark in the Scottish FA’s Project Brave initiative just a year after restructuring operations.The -year-old, who spent  years as a player at Tannadice and many more in ious back-room roles, believes the club has made great strides to become “frontrunners” in youth football rather than looking at others with envy.“We’re hopeful here, with the good environment and discipline instilled into them, that we can get results,” Bowman said.“We’ve got everything available now because of the work done by the owners and Tony Asghar.“With them coming in it’s sort of evolved the whole thing. We used to be jealous of what other clubs were doing before but we’re now probably one of the frontrunners.“We’re doing a lot of things other teams are aspiring to do. Because of the money and finance put in, it certainly makes your job a lot easier and helps a long way.“When you’re attracting young players to join the club, you want the kids to come into an elite environment rather than what it was before.“We weren’t bad before but there was no finance to do it properly. Andy Goldie is driving it on and we’ve managed to get to Elite status which is brilliant.“Restructuring the whole thing has meant new faces have come in with new ideas.“It’s about evolving all the time, you can’t just sit and accept it because that’s what was happening  or  years ago.”That said, Bow still believes attitude is what will help players get to where they want to be, citing former United man and Liverpool star Andy Robertson as an example.“That’s one of the biggest things I see with kids that are talented,” he added.“It’s how you install it into them to give that extra %. When you come out the other end of an academy, that’s the bit that will help you.“You need to be disciplined. Even since I played, and it’s changed a lot since then, football’s been like that.“You can’t go out every night, you’ve got to practice things and get the basics right first before you work on your game.“We’re wanting to give them the whole package by putting all the fragments together and glue them so we get better players at the end of the day. vw, px"  “I’m a great believer in always getting to where you want to go.“You could stay here, play in the first team and,you’re good enough, you could always move.“We’ve had one recently with Banksy .“Andy Robertson is a fine example, to have came from Queen’s Park then come up here.“From us he probably could’ve gone straight to a Liverpool or a higher team but he went to Hull and earned his stripes.“Sometimes they want to accelerate it and get from down at E right up to A straight away, rather than working their way up.“That’s the way it goes sometimes and I’ve seen others like wee Gauldy .“I’d have put my mortgage on wee Gauldy being a success at Sporting eventually but, unfortunately for him, things turn out dferent ways.“He’s still playing in Portugal, of course, but he was the one I thought would’ve kicked on.“If I’d looked at Andy and Gauldy back then I’d have probably said Gauldy was the better player. It says a lot about Andy’s character as well and his real drive and determination.”Not everyone can be Andy Robertson, though, Bowman concedes.“I always think the Dutch are a brilliant example because even when players leave the likes of PSV and Ajax, they’ll go where.#Whereas, sometimes in Scotland they’ll drop out of academies and then football altogether.“We’d like to see those boys progress and keep playing as well. That’s a big part of my job, too.“I hope that when they come in full-time with us, they’ll aspire to be players at one level or another.“They’ve just got to show what they’re about.
